title: Cotización del Dólar en Venezuela este lunes 26 de mayo 2025
content: 27-05-25.-El precio del dólar en el Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV) se cotizó este lunes 26 de mayo 2025 en Bs.95,23 por unidad según la última actualización en su página web oficial y redes ...
resumen: El precio del dólar en el Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV) se cotizó este lunes 26 de mayo 2025 en Bs.95,23 por unidad según la última actualización en su página web oficial y redes sociales. El euro se cotizó en Bs.108,38. El tipo de cambio que publicó el BCV es el promedio ponderado que resulta de las operaciones diarias de las mesas de cambio activas de las instituciones bancarias participantes. Por otro lado, el dólar paralelo en diversas plataformas en la jornada de hoy cerró en un promedio de Bs.135,26 la unidad, según Monitor-Noticias Venezuela.

title: Delegación de Guatemala inicia reuniones en EE. UU. por tema arancelario
content: Los funcionarios guatemaltecos entregaron al Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos un informe en el que se responde a las barreras comerciales identificadas.
resumen: Una delegación de alto nivel del Gobierno de Guatemala comenzó el martes 27 de mayo con reuniones en territorio estadounidense en seguimiento a aspectos relacionados con la tarifa arancelaria aplicada por la administración del presidente de EE. UU., Donald Trump. La delegación se reunió con el representante comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR), embajador Jameson Greer y su equipo, para plantear la importancia y la urgencia de que este proceso avance para una solución favorable para Guatemala y que fortalezca el comercio entre los dos países. El grupo de funcionarios guatemaltecos está encabezado por el ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, embajador Carlos Martínez; la ministra de Economía, Gabriela García; y el embajador de Guatemala en los Estados Unidos, Hugo Beteta. Se entregó un informe a esa oficina, el cual responde a las áreas identificadas en el más reciente reporte de barreras comerciales elaborado por el USTR, incluyendo: Acciones en materia de modernización aduanera, Facilitación del comercio, Mejora de estándares fitosanitarios, Protección a la propiedad intelectual y modernización aduanera y portuaria. La Cancillería informó que la delegación tendrá alrededor de 20 reuniones "con asociaciones empresariales, agencias del Gobierno de EE.UU. y representantes del congreso estadounidense" en busca de reforzar las relaciones comerciales entre ambos países. En abril pasado, el Gobierno estadounidense impuso un gravamen del 10 % a los productos procedentes de Guatemala. Durante los primeros tres meses del año, antes de la imposición de aranceles, el ingreso de divisas por las exportaciones guatemaltecas aumentó 10,7 %.

title: Guatemala negocia con EE. UU. eliminación de arancel del 10% y delegación oficial se reunió con Jameson Greer, representante del USTR
content: La delegación del gobierno de Guatemala inició oficialmente este 27 de mayo las conversaciones con las autoridades de comercio de Estados Unidos para que se elimine el arancel del 10% para la ...
resumen:
El 27 de mayo de 2025, la delegación del gobierno de Guatemala inició oficialmente las conversaciones con las autoridades de comercio de Estados Unidos para que se elimine el arancel del 10% para la importación de productos guatemaltecos a ese país.

Los funcionarios de Guatemala como la ministra de Economía, Gabriela García; el ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, Carlos Ramiro Martínez; y el Embajador de Guatemala en Washington, Hugo Beteta, se reunieron con el Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR), embajador Jameson Greer, para negociar eliminación de aranceles del 10%.

La reunión se llevó a cabo con el Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR), embajador Jameson Greer y su equipo.

En la reunión con USTR el Gobierno de Guatemala confirmó la solicitud formal para iniciar el diálogo con el objeto de abordar los temas relacionados con el arancel del 10% y las barreras no arancelarias.

La comitiva de Guatemala es encabezada por el ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, Carlos Ramiro Martínez y la ministra de Economía, Gabriela García, quienes participaron en la reunión junto al Embajador de Guatemala en Washington, Hugo Beteta.

El gobierno de Guatemala entregó el informe que responde a las áreas identificadas en el más reciente reporte anual de barreras comerciales que fue elaborado por el USTR, que incluyen acciones en materia de modernización aduanera, facilitación del comercio, mejora de estándares y fitosanitarios, protección a la propiedad intelectual y modernización portuaria.

El embajador Greer reconoció la estrategia planteada por Guatemala y expresó satisfacción de contar, desde el inicio, con una hoja de ruta y resultados concretos obtenidos a la fecha.

La comitiva de Guatemala está acompañada por alrededor de 15 delegados del sector privado del país, que incluye directivos del Comité Coordinador de Asociaciones Agrícolas, Comerciales, Industriales y Financieras (Cacif) y diferentes cámaras empresariales.

En reunión entre funcionarios de ambos países Guatemala presentó el informe de acciones “que da respuesta a las preocupaciones expresadas en el más reciente reporte de barreras comerciales” y una carta de respaldo firmada por empresas guatemaltecas y estadounidenses que apoyan la solicitud de restablecer el acceso preferencial a productos de exportación de Guatemala.

La delegación de los sectores público y privado sostendrán alrededor de 20 reuniones durante esta semana con asociaciones empresariales, agencias del Gobierno de Estados Unidos y representantes del Congreso de dicho país.

title: La confianza del consumidor en EEUU repunta tras 5 meses de caídas y tensiones arancelarias
content: La confianza del consumidor en Estados Unidos registró un aumento de 12,3 puntos en mayo, alcanzando un índice de 98. Este repunte se da tras cinco meses de caídas por el impacto de los aranceles.
resumen:
La confianza del consumidor en Estados Unidos registró un aumento de 12,3 puntos en mayo, alcanzando un índice de 98. Este repunte se da tras cinco meses de caídas por el impacto de los aranceles.

El índice de confianza del consumidor, según el informe de The Conference Board publicado el martes, se incrementó 12,3 puntos en mayo, alcanzando un valor de 98 en comparación con 85,7 en abril, el más bajo desde mayo de 2020, durante el punto crítico de la pandemia.

La medida que refleja las expectativas a corto plazo de los estadounidenses con respecto a sus ingresos, las condiciones empresariales y el mercado laboral creció 17,4 puntos, posicionándose en 72,8.

El porcentaje de consumidores que consideran que una recesión es probable en Estados Unidos dentro de los próximos 12 meses también se redujo con respecto a abril.

Las medidas de política agresiva implementadas por Trump, incluidas las altas tasas de importación, han oscurecido las perspectivas de la economía y el mercado laboral, intensificando los temores sobre una posible recesión.

Trump había anunciado previamente un arancel del 145% sobre la mayoría de los bienes provenientes de China, pero acordó un paro de 90 días para llevar a cabo negociaciones. Además, Estados Unidos alcanzó acuerdos con el Reino Unido y la Unión Europea.

The Conference Board destacó que el incremento en la confianza de este mes se sintió en todos los grupos de edad e ingresos.

Las opiniones de los consumidores sobre la situación económica actual también mostraron mejoras, aunque las percepciones sobre la disponibilidad de empleo se deterioraron por quinto mes consecutivo, pese a que se reportó un sólido informe laboral reciente en el país.

Menos del 25% de los consultados expresaron inquietudes sobre perder su empleo, en contraste con el 50% que manifestó su preocupación por no poder adquirir los productos necesarios o deseados.

El Departamento de Trabajo informó que los empleadores estadounidenses incorporaron 177.000 nuevos puestos de trabajo en abril, manteniendo una tasa de desempleo del 4,2%.

title: Trump pospone aranceles del 50% a la Unión Europea hasta julio
content: Donald Trump anunció la postergación de los aranceles del 50% a productos europeos hasta el 9 de julio, luego de una llamada con Ursula von der Leyen.
resumen: Donald Trump anunció la postergación de los aranceles del 50% a productos europeos hasta el 9 de julio, luego de una llamada con Ursula von der Leyen. La decisión busca evitar una escalada en la guerra comercial y ha generado alivio en los mercados financieros. El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, decidió retrasar la implementación de aranceles del 50% a las importaciones de la Unión Europea, inicialmente previstos para el 1 de junio. La nueva fecha límite es el 9 de julio, otorgando a ambas partes un margen para avanzar en las negociaciones comerciales. La decisión se produjo tras una conversación telefónica entre Trump y la presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, quien solicitó más tiempo para alcanzar un acuerdo. “Tuvimos una llamada muy agradable y acordé retrasarlo”, declaró Trump, destacando la disposición de la UE para entablar negociaciones serias. Por su parte, von der Leyen expresó en redes sociales que la Unión Europea está lista para avanzar rápidamente en las conversaciones, subrayando la importancia de la relación comercial transatlántica. La decisión de Trump fue recibida con alivio por parte de los líderes europeos. El primer ministro italiano, Giorgia Meloni, propuso una cumbre entre líderes de la UE y Trump durante la próxima reunión de la OTAN en junio, buscando consolidar un acuerdo antes de la nueva fecha límite. Los mercados financieros reaccionaron positivamente al anuncio. Las bolsas europeas registraron alzas, con el DAX alemán subiendo un 1,5% y el CAC 40 francés un 1%. En Estados Unidos, los futuros del S\&P 500 y el Nasdaq también mostraron incrementos, reflejando el optimismo de los inversores ante la posibilidad de evitar una escalada en la guerra comercial.

title: La movida de Christian y Yuyo Daes para que Tecnoglass siga imparable con sus ventanas en la Florida
content: Invirtió USD 30 millones para quedarse con activos de Continental Glass Systems y asegurar mercado gringo mientras se preparan para montar una planta en EE. UU.
resumen: Christian y Yuyo Daes invirtieron USD 30 millones para adquirir activos de Continental Glass Systems, empresa con sede en La Florida, dedicada a la fabricación de vidrio arquitectónico y ventanería en Estados Unidos. Los hermanos Daes anunciaron la estrategia de internacionalización Tecnoglass, buscando un terreno para construir una planta de producción de marcos de aluminio y vidrio para ventanas en territorio americano, complementando la producción de su mega fábrica de Barranquilla. Tecnoglass, a través de su filial Energía Solar Windows, es responsable de cerca del 4% de las exportaciones totales hacia Estados Unidos. La empresa barranquillera tuvo ingresos de $954.000 millones en el primer trimestre, un 15,4% más que en el mismo periodo del año anterior.

title: Costco podría aumentar estos 5 alimentos por la implementación de aranceles
content: La política arancelaria que impondrá el presidente Donald Trump afecta el precio de diferentes productos importados al país ...
resumen:
La política arancelaria que impondrá el presidente Donald Trump afecta el precio de diferentes productos importados al país.
Ron Vachris, CEO de Costco, afirmó que los precios bajos se podrían mantener y “enfrentar este desafío aprovechando nuestro poder de compra global, sólidas relaciones con proveedores e innovación”.
Es posible que esta política arancelaria impuesta por Donald Tump, afecte los costos de algunos productos que tiene en sus estanterías.
Estos son algunos de los artículos que podrían irse al alza, consecuencia de los aranceles:
Extracto puro de vainilla: Actualmente tiene un costo de $13.99 por 16 onzas líquidas. El producto se elabora con vainas de vainilla importadas, principalmente de Madagascar, país al que se le aplicaría un arancel de 47% a partir de julio.
Café colombiano: De la marca Kirkland Signature tiene un costo actual de $22.49 por 3 libras. El país aún está sujeto al arancel del 10% impuesto a todos los países.
Aceite de oliva virgen extra italiano Kirkland Signature: Italia está sujeta a un arancel general del 10%. Actualmente se puede adquirir en Costco por $27.99 en una presentación de 2 litros.
Canela molida orgánica de Saigón Kirkland Signature: Los compradores pueden llevar el artículo, hasta ahora, por $19.99 por dos envases de 10,7 onzas.
Surtido de chocolate con leche Bouchard Napolitains: El precio actual es de $54,99 por 4 libras.

title: Trump elogia a la UE por acelerar las negociaciones tras su amenaza de un arancel del 50%
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, se ha mostrado satisfecho con la reacción de la Unión Europea de acelerar las conversaciones comerciales tras su amenaza de fijar un arancel del 50% para ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, se ha mostrado satisfecho con la reacción de la Unión Europea de acelerar las conversaciones comerciales tras su amenaza de fijar un arancel del 50% para los productos procedentes de Europa.

Trump aseguró a través de su perfil en la red social Truth: "Me acaban de informar de que la UE ha llamado para fijar rápidamente las fechas de la reunión. Este es un evento positivo, y espero que, FINALMENTE, al igual que mi exigencia a China, abran las naciones europeas al comercio con los Estados Unidos de América. ¡AMBOS estarán muy contentos y tendrán éxito si lo hacen!".

El inquilino de la Casa Blanca ha recordado que cuenta con la autoridad para "ESTABLECER UN ACUERDO" comercial para los Estados Unidos si no se puede llegar a un acuerdo o si considera que son tratados injustamente.

El comisario de Comercio de la UE, Maros Sefcovic, trasladó a Estados Unidos su "pleno compromiso" con alcanzar un acuerdo que beneficie a ambas partes, después de que el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, amenazase el pasado viernes con imponer aranceles del 50% sobre los productos europeos a partir del 1 de junio.

title: Trump's tax bill jeopardises clean power factory plans
content: Tax credit cuts in President Trump's budget bill have slowed the expansion of U.S. clean energy manufacturing, risking efforts to establish a fully American supply chain.
resumen:
Cuts to tax credits in President Trump's House budget bill are curtailing the rapid expansion in U.S. clean energy manufacturing capacity.

Biden's 2022 Inflation Reduction Act accelerated solar, wind and battery storage deployment and spurred new clean energy manufacturing projects. The act provides tax credits to clean power developers, incentives to buy domestic content and offers 45X advanced manufacturing production tax credits to suppliers that build factories in the United States.

Trump’s House budget bill proposes to speed up the expiry of the tax credits for developers and block the 45X manufacturing tax credits from going to foreign entities of concern (FEOC). The bill was narrowly approved by the House of Representatives on May 22.

Manufacturers have spent more than $321 billion in clean technology manufacturing since the inflation act was introduced in 2022. A total of 2,369 new clean energy manufacturing, utility-scale clean electricity and industrial decarbonisation facilities have opened since 2022, creating nearly 13,000 jobs in Texas and 12,500 in Georgia.

Many manufacturers are pausing expansion plans until the final bill is approved by Congress.

The proposed block on manufacturing credits for foreign entities of concern seems to apply to Chinese-owned companies and also companies “that have a licensing agreement with or receive any material assistance from a Chinese-owned company” and this would impact a significant amount of existing and planned U.S. solar manufacturing capacity.

For solar manufacturer Heliene, major amendments to the 45X production tax credits are the first concern, but the accelerated expiry of other tax credits would "also directly affect demand.” Heliene and Indian partner Premier Energies plan to develop the first module manufacturing chain to use U.S.-made polysilicon, wafers and cells but the final decision is still pending.

Manufacturers have already held back investments following Trump’s appointment as President, due to looming tax credit cuts and a raft of import tariff announcements.

Almost $8 billion in investment and 16 new large-scale clean energy factories and other projects were cancelled, closed, or downsized in Q1 2025.

President Trump has raised import tariffs to boost American manufacturing and gain leverage in international trade but volatile trade policies have deterred investors and U.S. clean energy manufacturers will likely face increased costs if the tariffs are implemented as proposed.

China dominates the global supply of solar components and imports into the United States from China and Southeast Asian countries, where many Chinese companies have relocated production, are subject to tariffs and antidumping and countervailing duties. President Trump has imposed an additional 30% tariff on imports from China as well as a 25% tariff on all steel and aluminium imports.

The inflation act led to a rapid increase in U.S. module production capacity, reaching 55 GW in May 2025, compared with just 8 GW in 2022. The U.S. is forecast to install around 40 GW of solar capacity per year in the coming years.

U.S. solar cell production capacity was just 8 GW/year in Q1 2025.

U.S. polysilicon capacity is currently around 26 GW/year but there is minimal wafer production capacity.

President Trump waylaid the burgeoning U.S. offshore wind sector by pausing the review of leases and permits and ordering the review of approved projects.

The Department of Interior rescinded a stop work order on Equinor's $5 billion Empire Wind project off New York.

Empire Wind will consist of 54 large offshore wind turbines of capacity 15 MW and the manufacturing facility will create up to 550 direct jobs.

title: Proactive approach to trade talks in a shifting global economy
content: The global trade landscape is witnessing significant disruptions following Trump's tariffs, with countries navigating the fallout and rearranging trade relations in a post-American world trade order.
resumen:
The global trade landscape is witnessing significant disruptions following Trump's tariffs. Countries are navigating the fallout and rearranging trade relations in a post-American world trade order.

United States President Donald Trump's aggressive tariff offensive, initiated on April 2, has sent shockwaves through the global trade system. Rooted in the Grievance Doctrine, these tariffs have ushered in a period of uncertainty and instability. This approach lacks a sound economic rationale and risks upsetting the multilateral trade system. The Grievance Doctrine underscores a shift toward protectionism in US trade policy.

The actions of nations in response to the disruptions from these tariffs have led to a reshaping of global trade dynamics, revealing new political economic pressures at play. Trump's tariff-driven approach also risks undermining long-term investments, disrupting supply chains and straining relationships with trading partners, including Indonesia. The erratic decision-making and lack of a coherent strategy have put the US on a path away from a rules-based global trade system toward protectionism, with repercussions felt globally.

Indonesia finds itself at a critical juncture in the shifting global trade landscape following the aftermath of Trump's tariff offensive and the resultant recalibration in international trade dynamics. As the country adapts to a post-American world trade order fraught with new political and economic pressures, it faces substantial challenges outlined in the US Trade Representatives (USTR) Report 2025, which underscore areas of improvement across various trade-related aspects such as tariffs, non-tariff barriers, technical barriers, intellectual property protection and more.

The recent developments in the US-China Trade War, featuring a temporary 90-day "ceasefire" agreement, add another layer of complexity to Indonesia's trade strategies. The conflict, initiated by Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum in March 2018, triggered retaliatory actions from China, leading to escalating tensions and subsequent negotiations. Despite signing a Phase One Deal aimed at reducing tariffs and boosting US exports to China, disagreements over compliance have reignited friction, leaving Indonesia in a delicate balancing act amid threats of reciprocal tariffs and sovereignty concerns.

title: European Midday Briefing: Stocks Edge Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
content: Consumer prices were 0.6% higher on year this month, down from 0.9% in April, according to EU-harmonized figures published Tuesday by France's statistics agency Insee. Economists had expected May's ...
resumen:
European stocks ticked higher Tuesday on easing trade tensions, with Germany's DAX hitting a record high. The European Union agreed yesterday to fast-track talks with the U.S., after President Trump on Sunday pushed back plans to impose a 50% tariff on the bloc.

Stock futures rose as markets returned following the Memorial Day holiday. All eyes will be on a consumer confidence survey for May. Another preliminary survey from University of Michigan released earlier pointed towards further weakening in consumer sentiment in early May.

The euro slipped against the dollar. The dollar fell as uncertainty over U.S. tariffs remains elevated. The DXY dollar index could fall to 98.000.

The 10-year Bund yield fell, and is expected to hover around 2.5% for now amid trade difficulties between the U.S. and Europe. A fall to 2.2% is possible "if there is lasting re-escalation". UniCredit expects eurozone government bond supply to decline in June but to remain above 100 billion euros. Eurozone sovereigns have issued 660 billion euros in government bonds year-to-date, equivalent to more than 50% of their total issuance objectives for the year. Yields on U.K. government bonds fell, tracking moves in eurozone bonds, as trade tensions ease. Long-end Treasury yields dropped as investors returned to the market with caution, awaiting May's consumer confidence survey.

Oil prices slipped with investors looking ahead to OPEC's meeting on Sunday to review its supply agreement. Lower prices in 2025 through 2026 could lead to an earlier and lower peak for U.S. shale production, Goldman Sachs said.

Gold futures slumped, extending losses seen on Monday. Signs that Trump is easing his stance on trade with the EU has dented safe-haven demand, ANZ said.

The U.S. Marines recently took position in a field on this sleepy Swedish island about 200 miles from the Russian city of Kaliningrad and fired their mobile rocket system.

Thyssenkrupp plans to make all of its divisions independent and open to outside investment, a major overhaul that aims to turn the German industrial group into a holding company after more than two centuries as a manufacturer. The company said Monday that it would start preparations to separate its materials-services and automotive-technology segments in the coming years and that its decarbonization-technologies unit would follow suit. It aims to retain a majority interest in its businesses in the medium term.

Consumer sentiment in Germany improved a little as wage expectations grew and views of the economic outlook calmed, despite the uncertainty provoked by President Trump's tariff policies, a monthly survey said Tuesday. The consumer-climate index published by research groups GfK and the Nuremberg Institute for Market Decisions ticked up for a third straight month to minus 19.9 in June's forecast, 0.9 points higher than in May. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected the measure a little stronger, at minus 19.6.

French inflation cooled more than expected in May, likely clearing the way to an expected European Central Bank interest-rate cut next month. Consumer prices were 0.6% higher on year this month, down from 0.9% in April, according to EU-harmonized figures published Tuesday by France's statistics agency Insee. Economists had expected May's rate to stay at 0.9%, according to economists polled by The Wall Street Journal.

To weather a trade war with the U.S., China is looking to its own consumers to keep the economy churning. Beijing has made bolstering domestic consumption a top policy priority for the first time, promising efforts to boost household spending. In one initiative this year, the government allocated 300 billion yuan, equivalent to around $42 billion, to expand a program that pays shoppers to trade in old vehicles or electronics for new ones.

Europe must maintain a steadfast commitment to open trade and bolster its legal and institutional foundations to raise the profile of the euro currency as confidence in the dominance of the U.S. dollar wanes, according to European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde.

President Trump on Monday said he was considering taking billions in grant money away from Harvard University and redistributing it to trade schools across the U.S.

President Trump posted on his Truth Social platform early on Memorial Day: "I am considering taking Three Billion Dollars of Grant Money away from a very antisemitic Harvard, and giving it to TRADE SCHOOLS all across our land".

Years before longtime Rep. Charlie Rangel became Harlem's longtime Democratic representative in Congress, he was an artillery specialist in the Korean War. In November 1950, near the North Korean village of Kunu-ri, the Chinese army encircled Rangel's unit. After being hit with shrapnel and leading dozens of soldiers to safety in a nighttime escape, Rangel was awarded a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star with valor.

The Air Force C-130 transport plane dipped down on the sun-baked airfield of this remote island in the northern Philippines, delivering a weapon system designed to give the U.S. an edge in the intensifying superpower standoff in the Pacific. The Navy-Marine Expeditionary Ship Interdiction System, or Nmesis, is an antiship missile launcher mounted on a remote-controlled truck. The dumbbell-shaped islet where it landed lies just 120 miles south of Taiwan.

title: Carney invites Mexico’s President to G7 summit, raising hopes for sideline tariff talks with Trump
content: Prime Minister Mark Carney has invited Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum to attend the Group of Seven Leaders’ Summit in Kananaskis, Alta., next month, two sources familiar with the matter say.
resumen:
Prime Minister Mark Carney has invited Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum to attend the Group of Seven Leaders’ Summit in Kananaskis, Alta., next month, according to two sources.
Ms. Sheinbaum’s inclusion would provide an opportunity for talks with U.S. President Donald Trump on his protectionist tariffs and the future of North America’s trilateral trade agreement.
It would be the first three-way meeting between the leaders of Canada, Mexico and the United States since Mr. Trump took office.
The Globe and Mail is not naming the two sources because they are not authorized to discuss the matter publicly.
Mexico’s embassy in Canada declined to confirm the invitation or to offer comment.
Goldy Hyder, president of the Business Council of Canada, has been pushing the Carney government to invite Ms. Sheinbaum to Kananaskis.
Mr. Hyder said that Mr. Trump has fondness for Ms. Sheinbaum.
The U.S. President’s trade war on Canada and Mexico, which began in March, is discouraging capital investment in Canadian industry and has driven up costs for consumers and businesses.
The G7 summit is being held just outside Calgary.
On May 6, during a face-to-face visit in Washington with Mr. Carney, Mr. Trump told journalists he’s not sure the trilateral United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) is still relevant.
In an interview with CBC’s Power and Politics on Tuesday, Mr. Carney said there have been intensive discussions since then to work out a trilateral trade deal.
He indicated that a deal could be struck before September.
Flavio Volpe, president of the Auto Parts Manufacturers Association, said he thinks the fact that Mr. Carney has invited Ms. Sheinbaum to the G7 indicates that continuing trade talks between Canada and the United States are going well.
Fen Hampson, a professor of international affairs at Carleton University, said he thinks future trade talks with the U.S. might lead to a set of sectoral agreements – on autos, or steel – that could potentially even replace the USMCA.
Mr. Hyder said the Prime Minister’s invitation to his Mexican counterpart will help repair strained relations because of mismanagement by former prime minister Justin Trudeau and comments of Premier Doug Ford.
Mr. Hyder has meet Ms. Sheinbaum on two recent occasions.
Mr. Hyder expects Mr. Trump will push hard for a common position on how to deal with China and its unfair trade practices.
Canada and Mexico have each been holding bilateral talks in Washington with the Trump administration on defence and security matters as well as critical minerals.
Mr. Hyder said International Trade Minister Dominic LeBlanc was in Washington last week for talks on these issues with U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick.
Canada’s ambassador to Washington, Kirsten Hillman, said earlier this month she sees discussions on security – including the illegal distribution of fentanyl – and matters such as critical minerals taking place separately from the renegotiation of the USCMA, which is up for renewal in 2026.
The current U.S. levies on Canada that remain in effect include 25-per-cent tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum, as well as a 25-per-cent tariff on Canadian-made vehicles, which applies only to the non-U.S. content in those cars and light trucks.
There is also a 25-per-cent tariff – which drops to 10 per cent on critical minerals, energy and potash – for goods that don’t comply with rules of origin in USMCA.
Canada responded with a series of countertariffs on tens of billions of dollars of U.S. imports.

title: Donald Trump steals Xi Jinping’s favourite foreign policy
content: In February Mr Trump halted graft investigations under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, blaming the law for erecting “excessive barriers to American commerce”. Though Mr Trump loves economic ...
resumen: China, a major economic and military power, often adopts a cautious and transactional approach to foreign policy, particularly in regions like the Middle East. This approach, focused on business deals and self-interest, has persisted under Xi Jinping, who presents China as a peace-loving giant to the world while emphasizing its global pre-eminence at home. China promotes prosperity through trade, technology, and infrastructure as a solution to regional conflicts, as seen with the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). China's foreign policy is often praised as "Chinese wisdom" by scholars. China has vetoed UN Security Council resolutions to impose sanctions on Syria. China's primary interest in Syria's civil war was the presence of Uyghur militants. China's response to problems is to call for mediation and suggest that Western intervention is the root cause. China favors opaque contracts and is a stingy aid donor. Donald Trump, the American president, shares a transactional approach to foreign policy, and is scornful of overseas aid. Trump praised Gulf Arab rulers for focusing on commerce rather than chaos. Trump halted graft investigations under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. China's economy is slowing, and BRI lending has peaked. China remains a major energy buyer and offers green technologies. Trump has given China cause to amp up the ideology, and push harder.

title: Tired of tariffs? 5 investments to step off the Trump tariff merry-go-round
content: Investors have seen a lot of volatility so far in 2025, as they try to grapple with the impact of new tariffs from the Trump administration on the economy. The S&P 500 rose to start the year, but fell ...
resumen:
In 2025, investors have seen volatility due to the impact of new tariffs from the Trump administration. The S&P 500 rose to start the year, but fell sharply, entering a bear market, following the announcement of the new tariffs on “Liberation Day.” The market has since recovered much of its losses.

Five tariff-resistant investments:

1.  **Gold:** Up more than 25 percent so far this year, and has risen about 6 percent since the tariffs were announced.
2.  **Real estate:** Real estate tends to be impacted more by local issues.
3.  **International stocks:** The Vanguard FTSE All-World ex-US ETF (VEU) is up about 14 percent this year as of mid-May, compared to a roughly 1 percent increase for the S&P 500.
4.  **Bonds:** Bonds may provide some protection during times of uncertainty.
5.  **Individual stocks or industries:** Tech companies such as Uber Technologies (UBER) and Netflix (NFLX) are up more than 45 and 30 percent, respectively, in 2025. Traditional defensive sectors such as consumer staples, health care and utilities may also be places to ride out the tariff storm.

title: iPhone exports from India to US surge 76% in April, but trade policies remain tricky
content: Omdia reports iPhone exports from India to the US rose 76% in April as Apple shifts assembly to India amid US-China trade tensions.
resumen:
iPhone exports from India to the US rose 76% in April.
Apple is shifting assembly from China to India amid trade tensions.
Apple plans to manufacture most US-sold iPhones in India.
Exports of iPhones from India to the United States rose by an estimated 76% year-on-year in April, according to data from Canalys, now part of Omdia.
Omdia estimates that 3 million iPhones shipped from India to the US in April, compared with 900,000 units from China—a 76% fall from the previous year.
The shift reflects Apple's long-term strategy to diversify production amid increasing tariffs.
Apple began strengthening its manufacturing presence in India during the Covid-19 pandemic.
India first overtook China in US-bound iPhone shipments in March.
Apple’s shipment volumes spiked ahead of the tariffs' introduction on April 2.
An exemption for iPhones and other consumer electronics was introduced on April 11.
Apple CEO Tim Cook confirmed in early May that most iPhones sold in the US will be manufactured in India going forward.
Tariffs on Chinese-made iPhones remain in effect, currently subject to an additional 30% duty, while imports from India face a 10% baseline rate.
Growth in iPhone exports from India is expected to slow in the coming months.
India’s manufacturing infrastructure is still developing and may not be able to meet full US demand before 2026.
Current quarterly demand for iPhones in the US stands at around 20 million units.
Most sub-assembly processes still take place in China.
Trump threatened to impose a 25% tariff on all iPhones sold in the US unless they are manufactured domestically.
China has also reportedly imposed restrictions on the transfer of machinery and skilled labour to India.

title: Trump shock: Here’s a 4-D formula for policymakers to track it
content: As uncertainty rules high for companies, investors and governments, how matters move in terms of diversification, defence, debt and the dollar could help us gauge the impact of the Trump shock on the ...
resumen:
The article discusses a 4-D formula for policymakers to track the impact of the "Trump shock" on the Indian economy over the medium term, focusing on diversification, defence, debt, and the dollar.

Diversification: Countries may diversify their economic structures amid geopolitical uncertainty through bolstering manufacturing, depending more on domestic demand, increasing domestic savings, and restricting trade within regional economic zones. A higher share of wages in national income may be needed to support local consumer spending.

Defence: Global military spending increased in real terms at the fastest rate since the end of the Cold War in 2024. India may need to increase its military budget, potentially doubling it to 4% of GDP.

Debt: Bond markets are threatening action against countries with high public debt. India's public debt-to-GDP ratio is projected to decrease marginally between 2024 and 2030, with most government debt held by domestic investors.

Dollar: The US dollar has been the pivot of the global financial system. Concerns about the sustainability of US public finances are important. If the US dollar is toppled from its perch as the global reserve currency, it will impact every open economy that uses the US dollar as its main currency for international trade, whose central bank holds its reserves primarily in US dollar assets and whose exchange rate is maintained in some fixed or crawling leg to the US currency. India is one of those countries.

The author is Niranjan Rajadhyaksha, executive director at Artha India Research Advisors.

title: Japan Will Spend $6.3 Billion to Shield Its Economy From Trump’s Tariffs
content: Lawmakers approved a plan to help companies and consumers as officials bargain in Washington for relief from debilitating auto levies.
resumen:
Japan aprobó un paquete de gastos de $6.3 mil millones para "apoyar plenamente" a las empresas y los hogares afectados negativamente por los aranceles, dijo el secretario del gabinete Yoshimasa Hayashi en una sesión informativa. Los fondos reforzarán las finanzas de las pequeñas y medianas empresas y subsidiarán los costos de energía de los hogares.

El sector automotriz del país, la columna vertebral de la economía, ya se está tambaleando por un arancel estadounidense del 25 por ciento sobre automóviles y autopartes terminados.

Toyota Motor, la empresa más grande de Japón, ha proyectado un impacto de $1.3 mil millones en sus ganancias solo para abril y mayo debido a los aranceles. Honda Motor y Nissan Motor han pronosticado de manera similar fuertes caídas en sus ganancias. Nissan está considerando cerrar dos plantas en Japón como parte de sus esfuerzos de reestructuración. El fabricante de automóviles también planea trasladar parte de la producción de Japón a Estados Unidos para evitar los aranceles.

Los economistas han estimado que los aranceles automotrices más altos por sí solos podrían reducir significativamente la economía de Japón este año. Teniendo en cuenta las interrupciones más amplias causadas por las tensiones comerciales mundiales, los funcionarios han advertido que el crecimiento general podría reducirse a más de la mitad.

Antes de Japón, varios países reunieron fondos para ayudar a sus economías a hacer frente a la escalada de los aranceles. España dio a conocer un paquete de ayuda arancelaria de $15 mil millones el mes pasado. Canadá también ha destinado miles de millones de dólares para ayudar a sus trabajadores y empresas a capear el comercio turbulento con Estados Unidos.

El principal negociador de aranceles de Japón, Ryosei Akazawa, se reunió la semana pasada en Washington con sus homólogos de la administración Trump. Las conversaciones se han movido lentamente, estancándose al menos en parte porque los funcionarios de Trump han señalado que la principal demanda de Japón, una exención de los aranceles automotrices, no está sujeta a negociación.

El artículo fue escrito por River Akira Davis y Hisako Ueno.

title: Republican senator admits Trump is Canada’s ‘adversary’ as DC delegation grovels in Ottawa
content: Months of provocative statements about the Great White North joining America as the 51st state in the Union, however, led the delegation’s lone Republican member to admit to reporters that the US ...
resumen:
Washington’s delegation to Canada seemed to have one message in mind: please keep taking us seriously.

The delegation was split between four Democrats and one lone Republican senator representing a border state — North Dakota. Other Republicans stayed home.

Kevin Cramer, the GOP “co-leader”, told reporters that Prime Minister Mark Carney centered him in his conversation with the group, given the senator’s relationship with the Republican US president.

He told reporters that he sought to encourage Canadian officials to reach a trade deal with the United States.

Cramer said after the meetings Friday, according to Punchbowl News: “I don’t want to get in Donald Trump’s way. There’s no [trade] deal that happens without his involvement. But at the same time [I want to] be an encourager to Canada and their officials and try to be a partner in some way.”

Cramer did not take a beating on Truth Social, even though he did lay the blame for the fraying of ties squarely on Trump’s shoulders.

“We have an obligation to stop the offenses,” the Republican senator told reporters, speaking of the United States.

“For the moment, the United States has become an adversary to the Canadian people because of the offense that so many have felt,” he continued. “What I would stress with the president would be, let’s keep our eye on the common adversary and how much stronger we can be.”

Cramer said: “I’m just here to say thank you, and then to encourage Canadians to take another look and give us another chance.”

Tim Kaine pitched Carney on his bill to block US sanctions on Canada.

Senator Jeanne Shaheen said that she hoped some of the “cracks” in the bonds between the US and Canada could be healed.

Carney, elected on a Liberal Party mandate to stand up to the US president, flew to Washington in early May after telling the BBC in an interview that Canada would negotiate with America “on our terms”.

The Canadian prime minister reportedly invited Claudia Sheinbaum to the upcoming G7 summit in Kananaskis next month.

Carney told Trump that Canada was “not for sale” during their meeting at the White House in early May.

The US president wrote on Truth Social that he presented Canada’s government with a $61bn price tag to be involved with the US’s proposed “Golden Dome” missile defene system, adding that it would be free if Canada relented and became a state.

“They are considering the offer!” Trump said.

In an address scripted by the Canadian government, Charles declared that Canada, under Carney’s government, would bond with “reliable trading partners and allies” — a clear warning shot for Washington.

He’d add that Canada’s government was determined to protect the right to “self-determination” for the country.

Charles said on Tuesday: “We must be clear-eyed: the world is a more dangerous and uncertain place than at any point since the Second World War. Canada is facing challenges that are unprecedented in our lifetimes.”

title: Tech’s Trump Whisperer, Tim Cook, Goes Quiet as His Influence Fades
content: Apple’s chief executive has gone from winning President Trump’s praise to drawing his ire, deepening the company’s woes in a very bad year.
resumen:
In the run-up to President Trump’s recent trip to the Middle East, the White House encouraged chief executives and representatives of many U.S. companies to join him. Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, declined.

During his speech in Riyadh, Mr. Trump paused to praise Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, for traveling to the Middle East along with the White House delegation. Then he knocked Mr. Cook.

At an event attended by chief executives like Larry Fink of the asset manager BlackRock, Sam Altman of OpenAI, Jane Fraser of Citigroup and Lisa Su of the semiconductor company AMD, Mr. Trump said to Mr. Huang, “I mean, Tim Cook isn’t here but you are.”

Later in Qatar, Mr. Trump said he “had a little problem with Tim Cook.” The president praised Apple’s investment in the United States, then said he had told Mr. Cook, “But now I hear you’re building all over India. I don’t want you building in India.”

On Friday morning, Mr. Trump caught much of his own administration and Apple’s leadership off guard with a social media post threatening tariffs of 25 percent on iPhones made anywhere except the United States. The post thrust Apple back into the administration’s cross hairs a little over a month after Mr. Cook had lobbied and won an exemption from a 145 percent tariff on iPhones assembled in China and sold in the United States.

Mr. Trump’s new tariffs followed a report by The Financial Times that Apple’s supplier Foxconn would spend $1.5 billion on a plant in India for iPhones. The president said the tariffs would begin at the end of June and affect all smartphones made abroad, including Samsung’s devices.

During an appearance on Fox News on Friday, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the administration considered overseas production of semiconductors and electronics components “one of our greatest vulnerabilities,” which Apple could help address.

Kush Desai, a White House spokesman, said the administration “continues to have a productive relationship with Apple.”

Last month, the company suffered a stinging defeat in an App Store trial. The judge in the trial rebuked Apple executives, saying they had “outright lied under oath” and that “Cook chose poorly,” and ruled that Apple had to change how it operates the App Store. Jony Ive, Apple’s former chief designer who became estranged from Mr. Cook and left the company in 2019, joined OpenAI last week to build a potential iPhone competitor. Its Vision Pro mixed reality headset, released in January 2024 to fanfare, has been a disappointment. And in March, Apple postponed its promised release of a new Siri, raising fresh doubts about its ability to compete in the industry’s race to adopt artificial intelligence.

Apple’s market value has increased by more than $2.5 trillion under his leadership, or about $500 million a day since 2011. And Apple remains a moneymaking machine, generating an annual profit of nearly $100 billion.

In 2019, Mr. Trump said Mr. Cook was a “great executive because he calls me and others don’t.”

During an appearance at a conference for Fortune magazine in late 2017, Mr. Cook explained that the company would love to make things in the United States but that China had more engineers and better skills. He appeared before a live audience on MSNBC a few months later and criticized the president’s policy on immigration.

Apple has stopped short of committing to making the iPhone, iPad or Mac laptops in the United States. Instead, the company has moved to assemble more iPhones in India.

Apple has tried to head off Mr. Trump’s criticisms of its overseas manufacturing by promising to spend $500 billion in the United States over the next four years. Mr. Cook also has emphasized that the company will source 19 billion chips from the United States this year, and will start making A.I. servers in Houston.

He wants iPhones made in the United States badly enough to create what amounts to an iPhone tariff. It would increase the cost of shipping an iPhone from India or China to the United States by 25 percent.

“If they’re going to sell it in America, I want it to be built in the United States,” Mr. Trump said on Friday. “They’re able to do that.”

title: Acuerdo del litio: Morgan Stanley y fechas que no calzan; la irrupción de Río Tinto en el mercado
content: El gigante australiano se convirtió en el nuevo mejor amigo de Codelco y Enami y apunta a quitarle protagonismo a SQM y Albemarle. También en esta edición: una radiografía de en que gasta la plata el ...
resumen:
El contenido principal del texto es el siguiente:

*   **Acuerdo por el litio:**
    *   Codelco contrató a Morgan Stanley para negociar con SQM casi un mes antes de que se anunciara la Estrategia Nacional del Litio y dos meses antes de que Corfo enviara la carta a Codelco autorizando formalmente las negociaciones con SQM o terceros.
    *   Según analistas de la industria, la minera habría decidido a dedo optar por SQM tiempo antes de tener formalmente el mandato de Corfo para negociar un acuerdo para explotar litio en el salar de Atacama, y que los intercambios de cartas y negociaciones con la Corporación de Fomento de la Producción fueron un “mero formalismo”.
    *   Un consultor que asesora a mineras con interés en participar en el negocio del litio en Chile y que quedaron fuera, dice que la carta de Corfo a Codelco del 24 de mayo entregándole poder para negociar el salar de Atacama parece haber sido completamente simulada, dado que Codelco ya el 30 de marzo del 2023 tenía firmado con Morgan Stanley el acuerdo de asesor financiero para hacer un joint venture entre Codelco, Corfo y SQM ( y otro si fuera el caso).
    *   Rio Tinto fue seleccionada por Codelco para ser socia en Maricunga y por Enami en el proyecto de litio Salares Altoandinos.
    *   Menos de un mes antes de ser escogida, Rio Tinto había registrado los permisos para entrar a la minería del litio en Chile.
    *   Rio Tinto y Codelco firmaron un acuerdo en mayo para fortalecer su colaboración en el desarrollo de un distrito minero en la Región de Atacama, Chile, con foco en Nuevo Cobre.
    *   Rio Tinto lidera en el uso de una nueva tecnología, denominada extracción directa de litio (DLE), para separar el litio de la salmuera.
    *   Rio cuenta con una planta piloto de DLE en su proyecto Rincón, en Argentina, y recientemente ha adquirido la empresa estadounidense Arcadium.
    *   Cronología:
        *   20 de abril de 2023, el Presidente Gabriel Boric anunció la Estrategia Nacional del Litio en cadena nacional.
        *   12 de mayo de 2023: Codelco aprueba la creación de dos filiales para actividades de litio: Salares de Chile SpA y Minera Tarar SpA.
        *   22 y 24 de mayo de 2023: Corfo envía una carta a Codelco, autorizando formalmente las negociaciones con SQM o terceros. Codelco responde aceptando el mandato como único representante del Estado.
        *   25 y 26 de mayo de 2023: el presidente del Directorio de Codelco informa a este sobre el avance en el tema y, al día siguiente, se reúne con el gerente general de SQM, dando inicio formal a las negociaciones.
        *   26 de enero de 2023, Máximo Pacheco, presidente de la minera estatal, le informa a su Directorio que ha iniciado conversaciones con Corfo para buscar alternativas que aseguren la continuidad de la explotación de litio en el salar de Atacama post-2030. Se autoriza la firma de un Memorándum de Entendimiento (MOU).
        *   23 de febrero de 2023, se firma el MOU entre Corfo y Codelco.
        *   Codelco dice que una semana antes de que el Presidente Boric anunciara la Estrategia Nacional del Litio, en Directorio Extraordinario de Codelco se informa sobre el avance del MOU con Corfo, la contratación de Morgan Stanley, pero que aún no ha habido conversaciones con SQM.

    *   Diversos participantes coincidieron en que, si bien Chile enfrenta problemas estructurales, se está avanzando.

    *   Destacó la directiva presidencial para agilizar más de 100 proyectos, entre ellos, un proyecto de ley de descarbonización y una futura ley de incentivos tributarios para el hidrógeno verde.
*   **Gasto Público:**

    *   Chile gasta casi un tercio del presupuesto en protección social.
    *   Chile gasta el 20% en salud.
*   **Tenpo en Chile Day:**
    *   El CEO y Co-Founder de Tenpo, Fernando Araya participó en el panel sobre neobancos en el Chile Day.
    *   Fernando Araya destacó que la inteligencia artificial es clave para habilitar una banca hiperpersonalizada, la detección de fraudes en tiempo real y la reducción de costos operativos.

    *   En 2023 el Estado gastó US$ 1.543 millones en licencias médicas para funcionarios públicos.

title: Trump aceptó una prórroga de aranceles a la UE tras la llamada de Von der Leyen
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció que aceptó aplazar hasta el 9 de julio el arancel previsto del 50 % a las importaciones procedentes de la Unión Europea (UE).
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció que aceptó aplazar hasta el 9 de julio el arancel previsto del 50 % a las importaciones procedentes de la Unión Europea (UE). Trump escribió en su red social Truth Social, tras una llamada de la presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, quien solicitó una prórroga. Von der Leyen dijo que quiere ponerse a negociar en serio. En la red social X, la política europea calificó la llamada de "buena" y consideró que "Europa está dispuesta a avanzar en las conversaciones con rapidez y decisión". Trump había apuntado el viernes que las conversaciones con el bloque de 27 miembros "no iban a ninguna parte", amenazando con imponer un arancel del 50 % a todas las importaciones de la UE a partir del 1 de junio.

title: Trump Says Retailers Should ‘Eat the Tariffs.’ Good Luck With That.
content: Think again, Ms. Dahlhoff. Most grown-ups can handle the word “tariff.” The avoidance approach assumes that consumers are idiots who can’t figure out that they are paying a tax. Wordplay is a ...
resumen:
President Trump is ordering retailers like Walmart to abandon the principle that the cost of goods should not exceed actual revenues due to the 30 percent tariff on goods from China, as well as duties on items from Vietnam, Canada, Mexico and other major sources. Trump demanded that Walmart should “eat the tariffs” on Truth Social.

The head of the Small Business Administration, Kelly Loeffler, stated that “the top concern is not tariffs.”

Walmart announced it would have to raise some prices. According to UBS Global Wealth Management, a 10 percent tariff translates to a 4 percent price increase at retail.

Walmart sources many of its goods from Asia and particularly China.

Target has also warned it may raise prices.

Home Depot has said it will dial back in other areas or change their sourcing.

Upward of 70 percent of imported softwood products come from Canada — and the United States has threatened to raise the country’s current 14.54 percent tariff. For landscapers, some 80 percent of imported potash, which is used in fertilizer, is produced in Canada. Tariffs on aluminum and steel products sit at 25 percent.

Denise Dahlhoff, the director of marketing and communications research for the Conference Board, recommended that executives should avoid the word “tariff” and use more “neutral terms,” such as “sourcing cost” or “supply chain cost.”

A Danish furniture store in Westchester County, N.Y., recently posted signs explaining that its imported designs would be subject to a price increase of up to 10 percent as a result of the tariffs.

title: Trump dice tras conversar con Von der Leyen que «todo el mundo» quiere negociar con EE.UU.
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, aseguró este lunes que "todo el mundo" quiere negociar acuerdos comerciales con su país, que ha vuelto a ser "respetado". EFE/EPA/TIERNEY L CROSS / POOL ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, aseguró este lunes que "todo el mundo" quiere negociar acuerdos comerciales con su país, que ha vuelto a ser "respetado".

Trump hizo esta afirmación horas después de acordar en una llamada telefónica con la presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, la extensión del plazo hasta el 9 de julio para lograr un pacto con Bruselas.

Trump publicó en su red Truth Social: «Países de todo el mundo quieren hacer acuerdos comerciales con nosotros. ¡Es maravilloso! ¡Estados Unidos pronto experimentará un crecimiento tremendo y será más fuerte que nunca!».

En otro mensaje, Trump dijo: «Nuestra nación está protagonizando una de las recuperaciones más grandes y rápidas de la historia. En tan solo cuatro meses volvemos a ser respetados, respetados como nunca antes, y solo esperen, con billones de dólares invertidos en plantas y fábricas, a ver las cifras de CRECIMIENTO. ¡Esta es, sin duda, LA ERA DE ORO DE ESTADOS UNIDOS!».

En la conversación mantenida el domingo con Von der Leyen, que Trump calificó de «buena», el magnate inmobiliario aceptó la propuesta de Bruselas de extender la fecha límite para alcanzar un acuerdo.

Ese diálogo telefónico se produjo dos días después de que Trump amenazara con imponer a las importaciones de la Unión Europea (UE) un gravamen del 50 % al considerar que «no están yendo a ninguna parte» las conversaciones activadas desde que el propio presidente estadounidense impuso en abril una tregua de 90 días a la aplicación de sus llamados «aranceles recíprocos».

Trump había fijado originalmente el 9 de julio como fecha para mantener la pausa del «arancel recíproco» que le impuso a la UE, que, en caso de no haber acuerdo, pasaría de pagar el 10 % de aranceles que abona actualmente a un 20 % una vez rebasada esa fecha.

title: US-EU tariff talks resume after Trump blew up negotiations with threat of 50 percent hike
content: If the threatened tariffs go ahead after the new deadline of July, they will deliver a hammer blow to major European industries and economies.
resumen:
Negotiations between the Trump administration and the European Union (EU) on the tariffs imposed by the US on April 2 have resumed.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen initiated a phone call with US President Trump following his declaration on Friday that the US would impose a 50 percent tariff on all European goods from June 1.

Trump said he was “not looking for a deal” and that the deal is at 50 percent. He added that there could be a “little bit of a delay” if European companies “committed to moving manufacturing to the US.”

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the announcement was “in response to the EU’s pace.”

EU Trade Commissioner Maroš Šefčovič said the EU was committed to securing a deal that worked for both sides, but that trade between them “must be guided by mutual respect, not threats,” and that “we stand ready to defend our interests.”

The main points at issue go beyond the immediate question of reducing the trade surplus the EU enjoys with the US. One of the chief targets in the threats and negotiations from the US side is the European Value Added Tax. EU agricultural subsidies are another issue in US demands.

EU economics commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis told the WSJ that both issues were off the table.

Another major issue is what action the EU is prepared to take against China.

The US has so far not secured a commitment from EU leaders to place new tariffs on Chinese industries.

The US is the EU’s largest export market, accounting for 20 percent of its foreign markets and worth more than €530 billion ($US604 billion) in 2024.

Germany, Ireland, Italy and France are the leading exporters by country.

According to the research firm Capital Economics, a 50 percent US tariff on the EU would result in a 4 percent decline in GDP for Ireland. Germany’s GDP would contract by 1.5 percent, Italy’s by 1.2 percent, France’s by 0.75 percent, and Spain’s by 0.5 percent.

title: Ringgit opens higher against major, regional currencies as US confidence wanes after EU tariff delay
content: The ringgit opened higher against the US dollar today, buoyed by continued weakness in the greenback amid growing concerns over the United States’ ...
resumen:
At 8.05 am May 27, 2025, the ringgit rose to 4.2050/2250 against the US dollar compared with Monday’s close of 4.2155/2220.
The ringgit opened higher against the US dollar today, buoyed by continued weakness in the greenback amid growing concerns over the United States’ (US) fiscal trajectory and trade policy inconsistencies.
The US Dollar Index (DXY) had extended its downward trend, falling to 98.934 points.
The delay in implementing the 50 per cent tariff on European Union goods until July 9, 2025, signals uncertainty in the Trump administration’s trade stance.
The expansionary fiscal measures are expected to widen the US fiscal deficit and increase national debt levels.
Emerging market currencies, including the ringgit, continued to appreciate, supported by improving capital inflows and better risk appetite.
The ringgit gained vis-à-vis the euro to 4.7903/8131 from 4.7972/8046, rose against the British pound to 5.7058/7329 from 5.7175/7263, and expanded versus the Japanese yen to 2.9500/9643 from 2.9506/9553 on Monday.
The ringgit improved against the Singapore dollar to 3.2757/2915 from 3.2826/2879, strengthened against the Thai baht to 12.8992/9745 from 12.9231/9466, advanced vis-à-vis the Philippine peso to 7.58/7.63 from 7.60/7.62, and appreciated against the Indonesian rupiah to 258.7/260.1 from 259.4/259.9, previously.
Bank Muamalat Malaysia Bhd chief economist Dr Mohd Afzanizam Abdul Rashid.

title: US governors sidestep Trump, open trade talks with Canadian premiers
content: Six US governors seeking to sidestep the Trump administration’s trade war are inviting their Canadian counterparts to a meeting in Boston to discuss preserving the economic lifelines that have long ...
resumen:
Six US governors are inviting their Canadian counterparts to a meeting in Boston to discuss preserving economic ties. The invitation comes from five governors, mostly Democrats, representing New York, Maine, Connecticut, Rhode Island and Vermont. Premiers from Ontario, Québec, New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Labrador, Nova Scotia, and Prince Edward Island are likely to attend. The governors’ goal is to reinforce cross-border trade ties as Trump's tariffs are “making life increasingly more expensive for our people and our businesses.” The governors called the relationship “a cherished one, founded on mutual financial advantages and centuries-old familial and cultural bonds that supersede politics.”

The Healey administration warned that Trump’s tariffs on Canadian energy would raise gas and heating oil prices, potentially costing Massachusetts consumers nearly $1.36 billion annually, and up to $3.4 billion across the New England region. Canada is Massachusetts’ number one trading partner.

Trump’s tariffs are already being felt in Ontario, Canada's largest economy, where Honda paused its $15-billion EV supply chain project in Alliston, citing “changing market conditions” and US trade barriers. Ford, GM, and Stellantis have also slowed or suspended EV production, raising alarm over the future of a sector that supports over 100,000 jobs and contributes $36 billion in exports. A report from Ontario’s Financial Accountability Office warns that if tariffs persist, the province could lose up to 68,100 jobs this year — nearly doubling by 2029.

Romel Mostafa, director of the Lawrence National Centre for Policy and Management at Ivey Business School, said the Boston meeting presents a rare but important chance for provincial diplomacy to influence trade outcomes.

Newfoundland and Labrador welcomed the upcoming meeting. In 2023, Newfoundland and Labrador exported approximately $4.5 billion in goods to the United States — representing 37 per cent of its total exports. Between 60 and 80 per cent of the province’s seafood is sold to US markets. The province will soon open its first foreign office in Boston, co-located with Global Affairs Canada.

New Brunswick confirmed Premier Susan Holt has received the governors' invitation.

A coalition of cross-border Canadian and American mayors also warned that escalating US tariffs could severely damage regional economies. Representing over 270 municipalities through the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence Cities Initiative, the mayors called for urgent cooperation to avoid a trade war, stressing the region’s importance to more than half of Canada-US trade and over US$6 trillion in annual economic activity.

title: How Trump’s trade war is upending global economy
content: US PRESIDENT Donald J. Trump’s tariff decisions since he took office on Jan. 20 have shocked financial markets and sent a wave of uncertainty through the global economy. Here is a timeline of the ...
resumen:
US PRESIDENT Donald J. Trump’s tariff decisions since he took office on Jan. 20 have shocked financial markets and sent a wave of uncertainty through the global economy.

Here is a timeline of the major developments:

*   **Feb. 1** — Mr. Trump imposes 25% tariffs on Mexican and most Canadian imports and 10% on goods from China, demanding they curb the flow of fentanyl and illegal immigrants into the United States.
*   **Feb. 3** — Mr. Trump suspends his threat of tariffs on Mexico and Canada, agreeing to a 30-day pause in return for concessions on border and crime enforcement. The US does not reach such a deal with China.
*   **Feb. 7** — Mr. Trump delays tariffs on de minimis, or low-cost, packages from China until the Commerce Department can confirm that procedures and systems are in place to process them and collect tariff revenue.
*   **Feb. 10** — Mr. Trump raises tariffs on steel and aluminium to a flat 25% “without exceptions or exemptions.”
*   **March 3** — Mr. Trump says 25% tariffs on goods from Mexico and Canada will take effect from March 4 and doubles fentanyl-related tariffs on all Chinese imports to 20%.
*   **March 5** — The president agrees to delay tariffs for one month on some vehicles built in Canada and Mexico after a call with the chief executive officers of General Motors and Ford and the chair of Stellantis.
*   **March 6** — Mr. Trump exempts goods from Canada and Mexico under a North American trade pact for a month from the 25% tariffs.
*   **March 26** — Mr. Trump unveils a 25% tariff on imported cars and light trucks.
*   **April 2** — Mr. Trump announces global tariffs with a baseline of 10% across all imports and significantly higher duties on some of the US’ biggest trading partners.
*   **April 9** — Mr. Trump pauses for 90 days most of his country-specific tariffs that kicked in less than 24 hours earlier following an upheaval in financial markets that erased trillions of dollars from bourses around the world. The 10% blanket duty on almost all US imports stays in place. Mr. Trump says he will raise the tariff on Chinese imports to 125% from the 104% level that took effect a day earlier. This pushes the extra duties on Chinese goods to 145%, including the fentanyl-related tariffs imposed earlier.
*   **April 13** — The US administration grants exclusions from steep tariffs on smartphones, computers and some other electronics imported largely from China.
*   **April 22** — The Trump administration launches national security probes under Section 232 of the Trade Act of 1962 into imports of both pharmaceuticals and semiconductors as part of a bid to impose tariffs on both sectors.
*   **May 4** — Mr. Trump imposes a 100% tariff on all movies produced outside the US.
*   **May 9** — Mr. Trump and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer announce a limited bilateral trade agreement that leaves in place 10% tariffs on British exports, modestly expands agricultural access for both countries and lowers prohibitive US duties on British car exports.
*   **May 12** — The US and China agree to temporarily slash reciprocal tariffs. Under the 90-day truce, the US will cut the extra tariffs it imposed on Chinese imports to 30% from 145%, while China’s duties on US imports will be slashed to 10% from 125%.
*   **May 13** — The US cuts the low value “de minimis” tariff on China shipments, reducing duties for items valued at up to $800 to 54% from 120%.
*   **May 23** — Mr. Trump says he is recommending a straight 50% tariff on goods from the European Union (EU) starting on June 1. He also warned Apple it would face 25% tariff if phones it sold in the US were manufactured outside of the country.
*   **May 25** — Mr. Trump backpedals on his threat to slap 50% tariffs on imports from the EU, agreeing to extend the deadline for talks between the US and the block until July 9.

title: Bloques regionales como método de desarrollo
content: La Escuela de Economía de la PUCMM ha creado este espacio para que los estudiantes de la carrera compartan sus ideas a través de este prestigioso medio. Los artículos reflejan las perspectivas de estu ...
resumen:
Cuando hablamos de herramientas para el desarrollo económico de un país, es esencial destacar las ventajas del comercio internacional. El aumento de la competitividad, la disminución de los precios para los consumidores y la importación de tecnología que incrementa la productividad nacional son algunos de los múltiples beneficios que nos brindan estas transacciones con el exterior.

En muchos países se imponen barreras al comercio internacional, argumentando que este puede amenazar a los productores locales, quienes no siempre pueden competir con la eficiencia de los productores extranjeros, lo que podría llevar al cierre de empresas nacionales y poner en riesgo el autoabastecimiento. Además, estas barreras se usan en ocasiones como medidas para contrarrestar sanciones o incluso como instrumentos en guerras comerciales.

Una solución a los desafíos regulatorios de los mercados internacionales es la cooperación regional entre países. Estas alianzas, conocidas como bloques regionales, buscan afrontar retos comunes y promover intereses compartidos. Más allá del libre comercio, los bloques regionales también tienen un impacto en la diplomacia y en el desarrollo regional, incrementando la competitividad global.

El ejemplo más destacado de un bloque regional es la Unión Europea (UE), una asociación económica y política de 27 países europeos. La UE cuenta con instituciones que ejercen poderes ejecutivos, legislativos, judiciales y monetarios. En el ámbito económico, el Banco Central Europeo regula la política monetaria de 20 de los países miembros, los cuales comparten una misma moneda. Esto fomenta el comercio interno y asegura una política monetaria consistente.

Un caso ilustrativo de la dinámica económica en la UE ocurrió entre 2014 y 2019, cuando el Banco Central Europeo implementó una tasa de interés negativa debido a expectativas inflacionarias muy bajas. Esta medida, aunque problemática para economías tan diversas, mantuvo la inflación promedio por debajo del 1%, demostrando la interconexión entre las economías de la región.

Los bloques regionales también juegan un papel clave en la geopolítica. Por ejemplo, los BRICS han surgido como una alternativa al G7, agrupando el 43% de la población mundial, el 44% de la producción global de petróleo y el 28% del PIB mundial. Recientemente, se discutió la posibilidad de que los BRICS desafiaran al dólar estadounidense, lo que generó tensiones políticas y amenazas de aranceles por parte del actual presidente de USA, Donald Trump, aumentando las tensiones políticas entre ambos bloques.

Abrir una economía al comercio internacional suele tener efectos positivos al fomentar el crecimiento del aparato productivo y aumentar el bienestar general. Un claro ejemplo de cómo una economía cerrada al exterior es perjudicial para el bienestar y la producción fue visto en la política de Industrialización por sustitución de importaciones (ISI) propuesta por la CEPAL. En República Dominicana se adoptó este enfoque en a partir del 1968 que se enfocaba en la restricción de las importaciones mediante barreras arancelarias e incentivos financieros para el fomento de las industrias locales, que, aunque al principio consiguió consecuencias positivas al lograr la diversificación de la economía y promover el desarrollo de la industria local, la falta de competencia y dependencia en insumos importados provocó que el gobierno tuviese que desmantelar estas tendencias mercantilistas que, con la acumulación de riqueza, solo logró inflar los precios y devaluar la moneda.

Los bloques regionales son claves en el mundo actual por el carácter decisivo en elementos de desarrollo que pueden obtenerse como beneficio. También el hecho de estar tan alineado a la geopolítica lo hace un factor que incentiva a los países pertenecer a estos. Sin embargo, a la hora de establecer acuerdos regionales, nunca se debe de perder el foco principal, el cual es garantizar un mayor bienestar y desarrollo para todos los habitantes de la región.

title: Nvidia Q1 Preview: Trade War Troubles
content: Nvidia faces major risks from escalating US-China trade tensions, with Chinese competitors rapidly gaining market share. Read why NVDA stock is a Strong Sell.
resumen: Nvidia faces major risks from escalating US-China trade tensions, with Chinese competitors rapidly gaining market share and threatening Nvidiaâs international growth prospects. The companyâ99s premium pricing and high valuation multiples are unsustainable as the GPU market shifts toward total cost of ownership and lower-cost alternatives. Recent margin compression and negative EPS revisions signal that Nvidiaâs forward growth will likely underperform, justifying a strong sell rating ahead of earnings. Despite strong current demand from hyperscalers, the long-term outlook is challenged by trade war impacts and the rise of cost-focused global GPU competitors. Shares of GPU giant NVIDIA (NASDAQ:NVDA) (TSX:NVDA:CA) are down roughly 3.5% in the last six months and more than 2% year-to-date. This article was written by Noah's Arc Capital Management. Noah Cox (main account author) is the managing partner of Noahâs Arc Capital Management.

title: Tariffs, inflation worries loom. Lansing developments churning along for now
content: Building costs rose in the first quarter of 2025 by more than any four-month period in 2024, one cost index found.
resumen: The 25% steel and aluminum tariffs imposed by the Trump administration are expected to increase building costs. Uncertainty surrounding tariffs, inflation and the economy puts future projects "at higher risk," an economist said. Grand Avenue in downtown Lansing, for the next couple years at least, will be the center of much of the area's most significant new developments. Construction crews have broken ground on a new Lansing City Hall and affordable housing complex across the street from the Capital Area Transportation Authority's bus station. A 28-story skyscraper just a few blocks north is expected to become the city's tallest building when work is done in about two years. President Donald Trump's 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum imports took effect in March. In April, Trump's trade war ramped up with more announced tariffs before he paused some and increased those targeting China. The tariff announcements, last-minute changes and uncertainty have resulted in stock market drops and worries about continued inflation. Cristina Benton, a senior consultant with the East Lansing-based Anderson Economic Group, said steel and aluminum are fundamental components of the construction materials and there's also a 14.5% tariff in place for lumber for Canada and various appliances and fixtures made in countries around the world. Paul Gentilozzi, owner of Gentilozzi Real Estate, said steel costs for the New Vision Lansing project, the 28-story skyscraper that will have apartments and business, have already increased by $400,000, to $2.4 million. He's estimating a $2.5 million increase in costs over the next 18 months due to a combination of tariffs and price increases. Projects that have started are likely to continue because contracts with general contractors and vendors have already been signed, Benton said. Developer Pat Gillespie, whose company is involved in the Spartan Gateway District project at Michigan State University and will redevelop the former Sears site at Frandor, said he hasn't yet felt the impact of tariffs but has no reason to believe they will put the brakes on impending projects in the Lansing area. The Turner Construction Company, an international construction firm with an office in Michigan, releases a Turner Building Cost Index each quarter. The index reported a 1.18% increase in building costs in the first quarter of 2025. Gentilozzi isn't just keeping an eye on tariffs and inflation in an effort to keep costs low. A $400,000 a month interest payment during a build can be common. Gentilozzi said the New Vision building will have post-tensioned concrete for walls, floors and columns. The concrete has steel cables that run through them and are tightened as the concrete dries. Those cables are made in the Ukraine and take six months to produce, plus another month on a ship. Gillespie agreed that interest rates are probably a bigger issue than tariffs. Rising construction costs − whether caused by tariffs or other factors − may ultimately affect the size and design of buildings and even rental prices, Gillespie said.
