title: Geopolitical tensions lead to increasing risks for shipping sector globally
content: Despite geopolitical headwinds: only 27 large ships lost worldwide in 2024, down by more than 20%, the industry's lowest-ever total. Progress made on traditional risks such as fires, collisions, and ...
resumen:
Geopolitical tensions are creating new risks and challenges for the shipping industry, already dealing with the energy transition and the Covid-19 pandemic. The industry faces a volatile and complex operating environment, marked by attacks against shipping, vessel detentions, sanctions, and incidents involving damage to sub-sea cables. Increasing protectionism and tariffs threaten to reshape supply chains and trade relations.

90% of international trade is transported across oceans. The industry continues to see the potential for large claims from traditional risks such as fires, collisions, and groundings, which are still the main drivers for total losses of large vessels.

The shipping industry has made significant improvements in maritime safety in recent years. In the 1990s, the global fleet lost 200+ vessels a year. This total is now down to a record low of 27 as of the end of 2024 (from 35 in 2023).

US-China trade conflict and the growing shadow fleet bring uncertainty and challenges. Approximately 18% of global maritime trade was subject to tariffs as of mid-April 2025, compared with 4% in early March. The shadow fleet has grown significantly since the start of the war in Ukraine. Around 17% of the world tanker fleet is thought to belong to the shadow fleet; estimates indicate there are close to 600 tankers trading Russian oil alone. Shadow fleet vessels have been involved in tens of incidents around the world.

Cleanup costs for an oil spill involving a shadow fleet tanker could be as much as US$1.6bn.

Many ship operators have rerouted vessels around the Cape of Good Hope, adding time and cost to transits between Asia and Europe. Rerouting adds around $1mn in costs and at least 10 days to a typical transit between China and Europe. Cargo volumes in the strait had fallen by two-thirds by September 2024, with rerouting costing the global economy some US$200bn that year.

Large vessel fires remain a major concern. There were seven total losses reported across all vessel types during 2024, the same number as a year earlier. The number of incidents overall was up year-on-year to a decade high of 250, again across all vessel types. Around 30% of these fire incidents occurred on either container, cargo or roll-on roll-off vessels (ro-ros) (69). More than 100 total losses of vessels have been caused by fires in the past decade.

There are over 100,000 ships (100GT+) in the global fleet.

title: Volvo Cars Cuts 3,000 Jobs Amid Economic Pressures
content: Volvo Cars plans to lay off 3,000 employees, primarily in Sweden, as part of a cost-cutting initiative driven by economic uncertainties and trade tensions. The automotive industry faces challenges ...
resumen: Volvo Cars plans to lay off 3,000 employees, primarily in Sweden, as part of a cost-cutting initiative driven by economic uncertainties and trade tensions. The reductions include approximately 1,200 jobs in Sweden and an additional 1,000 consultant positions, mostly in Sweden. The remaining job cuts will affect global markets, predominantly targeting office roles. The CEO, Håkan Samuelsson, emphasized that these measures are crucial for bolstering Volvo's resilience. The automotive industry is grappling with several challenges, including heightened raw material costs and significant tariffs imposed by the US government. Owned by Geely of China, Volvo Cars employs 42,600 people and operates in Sweden, Belgium, South Carolina, and China.

title: Pharmacists stockpile medicines ahead of possible Trump tariffs on overseas drugmakers
content: They worry tariffs, aimed at bringing drug production to the United States, could instead drive companies out of business while raising prices and creating more of the drug shortages that have plagued ...
resumen: Pharmacists are stockpiling medicines due to potential tariffs on overseas drugmakers. Independent pharmacist Benjamin Jolley and his colleagues are concerned that tariffs, aimed at bringing drug production to the U.S., could raise prices and create drug shortages. President Donald Trump announced a 10% tariff on imported goods on April 2, with threats of additional tariffs targeting pharmaceuticals. The U.S. imported $213 billion worth of medicines in 2024. Pharmacists predict even the 10% tariffs will hurt. Scott Pace, a pharmacist, stocked up on the top 200 generics. Tariffs could be the death knell for independent pharmacies. Neal Smoller fears FDA firings will mean fewer federal inspections. Marta Wosińska said narrowly focused tariffs might work in some cases. John Murphy, CEO of the Association for Accessible Medicines, said tariffs won’t incentivize generic drug makers to build new factories in the U.S. Fresenius Kabi, a German company, complained that tariffs on raw materials could lead some companies to move finished product manufacturing overseas. Tariffs on biosimilars could incentivize U.S. use of more expensive brand-name biologics. European countries pay far less than the United States for brand-name products.

title: Defensa y respuesta a Trump, los temas que Asturias pide que se traten en la Conferencia de Presidentes
content: El Ejecutivo de Barbón también plantea analizar la red de 0 a 3 y esta vez aparca la siniestralidad laboral. Moncloa cerrará este miéercoles el orden del día de la cita d ...
resumen: El 6 de junio se celebrará la XXVIII Conferencia de Presidentes en el Palacio de Pedralbes, Barcelona. El Ejecutivo de Pedro Sánchez tiene la intención de centrarse en las políticas de acceso a la vivienda, la Formación Profesional y la universitaria. El Ministerio de Política Territorial remitió una carta a cada gobierno autonómico invitándoles a hacer sus propuestas antes del viernes. El Principado de Asturias respondió defendiendo un debate sobre las acciones coordinadas en materia de política arancelaria. El presidente asturiano, Adrián Barbón, se reunió con representantes de Fade, UGT y CC OO para presentarles un plan de respuesta a los aranceles anunciados por Donald Trump, que aspira a movilizar 30 millones para auxiliar a las empresas que más exportan a EE UU. El Ejecutivo asturiano quiere incorporar a la cita las inversiones en seguridad y defensa. España destina un 1,28% del PIB a esta materia (unos 15.958 millones). La OTAN presiona al gobierno español para que alcance el 5% del PIB. Asturias propone ampliar los puntos educativos propuestos por Moncloa para que se hable de la red de 0 a 3 años. La anterior Conferencia de Presidentes tuvo lugar en diciembre. El Principado solicitó incorporar la siniestralidad laboral, reforzar las políticas de salud mental y la lucha contra la violencia. La XXVII cita se limitó a tratar la financiación autonómica, la migración, la vivienda y la necesidad de refuerzos de personal en el sistema sanitario. Mañana miércoles tendrá lugar la reunión del comité preparatorio. El gobierno cántabro pidió analizar la financiación a la red de 0 a 3, la política migratoria, la energética y la financiación autonómica. La Xunta de Galicia reclamó los cuatro últimos temas.

title: Hang Seng Dips, Nikkei Gains as Trade Signals Drive Divergent Moves
content: Asian stock markets mixed as Trump’s tariff threats rattle Wall Street; Hang Seng dips, Nikkei gains on U.S.-Japan trade hopes.
resumen:
China’s state media warned of a prolonged US-China trade standoff, undermining hopes of a lasting deal.
The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.40% as trade jitters pressured property and tech stocks in early Monday trading.
The ASX 200 slipped 0.09% with Aussie bank stocks under pressure from higher US Treasury yields and weak sentiment.
US markets slumped as investors reacted to President Trump’s latest tariff threat.
The Nasdaq Composite Index slid 1%, while the Dow and S&P 500 dropped 0.61% and 0.67%, respectively.
On Friday, Trump threatened the EU with a 50% tariff, effective June 1.
The negative sentiment spilled into the Asian session on Monday, May 26.
CN Wire reported: “China must maintain a clear-eyed understanding of the challenges ahead, noting the U.S. may adopt delaying tactics to mitigate its economic losses. Given the enduring and complex nature of the confrontation, China must not only prepare thoroughly for negotiations but also brace for a prolonged struggle.”
Though the US and China recently agreed to a 90-day tariff pause, a lack of progress may spook investors as the deadline approaches.
Brian Tycangco, editor at Stansberry Research, commented: “As I’ve said previously, we just had a pause- not a deal. China isn’t under any illusion that this is an easy road to travel. Get ready for more volatility.”
The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.40% in early trade.
The Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index fell 0.10%, while the Hang Seng Tech Index rose 0.32%.
BYD Corp. (01211) and Li Auto (02015) rallied 1.97% and 1.07%, respectively.
The CSI 300 declined 0.17%, while the Shanghai Composite edged 0.05% lower.
Japan’s Nikkei 225 gained 0.88% on Monday morning as investors reacted to US-EU trade headlines.
On May 25, President Trump postponed the 50% tariff on EU goods from June 1 to July 9.
The US and Japan could resume trade talks as Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa prepares to visit Washington.
The USD/JPY pair by 0.05% to 142.619.
Tokyo Electron (8035) and Softbank Group (9984) advancing 1.96% and 1.49%, respectively.
Australia’s ASX 200 slipped 0.09% in the morning session as elevated US Treasury yields weighed on demand for high-yielding Aussie bank stocks.
Commonwealth Bank of Australia fell 0.43%, while ANZ slid 1.08%.
Northern Star Resources rallied 0.81%, following gold’s 1.89% surge on May 23.
Volatility remains elevated amid fiscal uncertainty and tariff concerns.
US-China negotiations will remain central to near-term sentiment.
Investors should monitor stimulus cues from Beijing and global central banks.

title: Gold consolidates at pivotal area ahead of US economic data and Fed signals
content: Gold (XAU/USD) continues to be caught between fundamental pressures and technical signals. Recent political and economic developments have created uncertainty, making traders cautious about taking ...
resumen:
Gold (XAU/USD) is caught between fundamental pressures and technical signals. Recent developments have created uncertainty, making traders cautious. After a strong rally last week, gold has slowed down.

Fundamental drivers for gold remain mixed but slightly tilted in favor of the yellow metal. US President Donald Trump's decision to delay the 50% tariff on the European Union until July 9 sparked some trade optimism. This reduced immediate fears of a trade war, applying short-term downward pressure on safe-haven assets like gold. However, that optimism is being offset by mounting fiscal concerns in the US. Trump's recently passed spending bill could expand the federal deficit by $4 trillion over the next decade. This has reignited worries over the country's financial stability.

Economic indicators continue to suggest a slowing US economy. Recent softer-than-expected readings in both the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and Producer Price Index (PPI) have increased the likelihood of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Traders are now pricing in at least two 25-basis-point cuts in 2025. Since gold is a non-yielding asset, a lower interest rate environment typically boosts its appeal to investors. In addition, geopolitical tensions remain high, particularly due to the ongoing war in Ukraine and the volatile situation in the Middle East. These conflicts support safe-haven demand and help limit deeper losses in gold despite occasional price corrections.

The weakness in the US Dollar also plays a key role in supporting gold prices. The greenback has been in a consistent downtrend for the past two weeks and has just hit a fresh monthly low. Since gold is priced in dollars, a weaker dollar makes it cheaper for foreign buyers and therefore boosts demand. Traders now await upcoming economic events for clearer direction. These include the FOMC meeting minutes and key US data releases such as Durable Goods Orders, GDP, and the PCE Price Index. Until these reports are released, the fundamental picture suggests that gold may find support on dips. However, it could face resistance in pushing significantly higher in the near term.

The gold chart shows a clear descending channel in its market trend. This pattern has existed since mid-April, guiding the price action with lower highs and lower lows. The price has recently reached the upper boundary of the descending channel, which has acted as a strong resistance in past attempts. Gold is once again testing this resistance around the $3,358 level. Support remains near the channel's lower boundary, which lies just above the $3,100 level. The dashed midline of the channel shows a key area of price equilibrium. Gold recently broke above it, suggesting short-term bullishness. However, the broader bearish trend remains intact unless the price decisively breaks out of the upper trend line.

title: Trump delaying 50% tariff on European Union
content: The president said Sunday he’s agreed to delay a 50% tariff on the EU that he threatened last week, after saying negotiations with the commission were “going nowhere.” ...
resumen: President Donald Trump has announced a delay on proposed tariffs on the European Union until July 9, 2025. The 50% tariff on EU goods would have kicked in starting June 1, but Trump said his agreement to an extension sets the new date at July 9, 2025. This decision followed a request from European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. Trump said he had agreed to the extension as a privilege. Trump said the 27-member bloc had been "very difficult to deal with." Trump posted on Truth Social Sunday evening, saying it was his "privilege" to have agreed to an extension, and said that von der Leyen said their talks will begin rapidly. Von der Leyen posted earlier on X that she had a "good call" with Trump. The EU and US share the world’s most consequential and close trade relationship. Europe is ready to advance talks swiftly and decisively. To reach a good deal, we would need the time until July 9. The core of Trump’s argument against the EU is that America runs a "totally unacceptable" trade deficit with the 27 member states. If implemented, a 50% tariff would be higher than the 30% tariff on China.

title: Apple has had few incentives in past to start making iPhones in US
content: Lashing out at Apple's plans to make most of its U.S. iPhones in India, President Donald Trump on Friday threatened to slap a 25 percent tariff on the popular device unless the tech giant starts ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened to slap a 25 percent tariff on the iPhone unless Apple starts building the product in the U.S.
Apple has been building most of its devices in China for decades, investing tens of billions of dollars on massive factories.
Apple CEO Tim Cook said that most iPhones sold in the U.S. during the March-June period would come from India.
Cook said the trade war would end up costing Apple an additional $900 million during the March-June period.
Industry analysts estimated the fees would drive up the cost of a $1,200 iPhone made in China to $1,500.
Analysts believe if Apple could start making iPhones in the U.S., prices would soar to at least $2,000 and possibly as high as $3,500.
The disincentives for Apple shifting its production domestically include a complex supply chain that Cook began to engineer during the 1990s.
It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build new plants in the U.S.
The price of an iPhone could triple, threatening to torpedo sales of Apple's marquee product, which generated revenue of $201 billion during the company's last fiscal year.
Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives estimated that the current $1,000 price tag for an iPhone made in China, or India, would soar to more than $3,000 if production shifted to the U.S.
Ives believes that moving production domestically likely couldn't be done until, at the earliest, 2028.
Ives predicted Cook would engage in a "game of negotiations" with Trump that would spare the iPhone from the 25 percent tariffs.
Apple executive Eddy Cue said that people may not need an iPhone 10 years from now.
Cook told investors that tariffs had a "limited impact" on the company in the March quarter.
Cook warned that it is "very difficult" to predict beyond June "because I'm not sure what will happen with tariffs."
Forrester Research analyst Dipanjan Chatterjee said that Apple continues to reap huge profit margins from the revenue generated by subscriptions and other services tied to its product, which collected $96 billion in revenue during Apple's last fiscal year.
U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick predicted tariffs would force a manufacturing shift.
Cook expressed doubt about whether the U.S. labor pool had enough workers with the vocational skills required to do the work.

title: ‘The best chance we’ve got’: Can Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent save the world from trade Armageddon?
content: As President Donald Trump conducted an impromptu news conference in Doha, Qatar, this month, surrounded by business leaders and top advisers, he made a point of singling out one person in particular.
resumen:
En una conferencia de prensa improvisada en Doha, Qatar, el presidente Donald Trump destacó a Scott Bessent, Secretario del Tesoro, quien había asegurado un acuerdo para pausar temporalmente la guerra comercial entre EE. UU. y China. Trump elogió a Bessent, afirmando que los mercados escuchan cuando él habla. Bessent, conocido por su discreción, respondió que tenían un plan y un mecanismo para evitar la escalada comercial.

Bessent es considerado el funcionario económico más importante del mundo, siendo el principal negociador de Trump con China, liderando conversaciones comerciales con otros países y participando en la elaboración de un paquete fiscal y de gasto. También es responsable de mantener el papel dominante de Estados Unidos en el sistema financiero global.

Bessent se ha convertido en una figura clave en la administración, ganándose la confianza de legisladores, funcionarios y ejecutivos. Ha tenido éxito en luchas internas para consolidar su rol y es visto por Wall Street como la mejor esperanza para moderar las políticas económicas de Trump.

Antes de unirse a la administración, Bessent estudió la biografía de William McKinley, un ídolo de Trump en materia de aranceles. Aunque subestimó el entusiasmo de Trump por los aranceles, escribió a inversores que era poco probable que se implementaran aranceles generalizados al mismo tiempo que se abordaba la crisis migratoria.

Bessent, ausente de la Casa Blanca y los medios de comunicación durante una reunión de ministros de finanzas del G7 en Canadá, fue objeto de comentarios sobre su importancia. Trump anunció la recomendación de aranceles del 50% a la Unión Europea y del 25% a los iPhones de Apple. Bessent, en Nueva York, fue entrevistado en Fox News y Bloomberg TV.

Antes de ser Secretario del Tesoro, Bessent participó en una operación financiera exitosa en 1992, trabajando para el fondo de cobertura de George Soros. Su experiencia incluye estudios en Yale y el trabajo con Jim Rogers, quien lo introdujo al mundo de las finanzas.

En 2017, Bessent buscó entender la administración Trump, conectando con Steve Bannon para comprender la visión económica de Trump. Bessent donó a republicanos y mantuvo relaciones positivas en Wall Street.

Bannon considera a Bessent un jugador clave en la gestión del mercado de bonos. Cuando las conversaciones lideradas por Bessent con China llevaron a una desescalada arancelaria, Bannon defendió a Bessent.

Bessent tiene una relación de larga data con la familia Trump y ha sido un defensor de causas LGBTQ. En una entrevista, Bessent relató un momento en el Despacho Oval con su familia, donde presenciaron el trabajo del gobierno.

Bessent predijo la victoria de Trump en 2023, basándose en el análisis de las acciones que suben con las malas noticias. Su decisión de ayudar a la campaña de Trump se basó en su preocupación por la deuda de EE. UU.

Bessent ha influido en las políticas de Trump, como la pausa en los aranceles. Su enfoque en el rendimiento del Tesoro a 10 años es notable.

En la Conferencia Global del Instituto Milken, Bessent explicó que los componentes principales de la agenda económica de Trump (comercio, recortes de impuestos y desregulación) son partes interconectadas de un motor diseñado para impulsar la inversión a largo plazo en la economía estadounidense.

Los asesores económicos de Trump enfatizan que su agenda incluye incentivos fiscales y regulatorios, junto con los aranceles, para impulsar la inversión y el crecimiento. Los aranceles están diseñados para encajar en un marco más amplio que se centra en los recortes de impuestos y la desregulación.

La agenda busca equilibrar los incentivos fiscales y la desregulación con los aranceles, para evitar una recesión. Si alguno de estos elementos falla, la política económica podría colapsar.

title: Malasia lista para la cumbre de la ASEAN con énfasis en guerra comercial, Gaza y Birmania
content: Kuala Lumpur, 25 may (EFE).- Malasia tiene todo listo para la cumbre de líderes de la Asociación de Naciones del Sudeste Asiático (ASEAN) que arrancará el lunes en Kuala Lumpur, con énfasis en la guer ...
resumen:
Malasia está lista para la cumbre de líderes de la Asociación de Naciones del Sudeste Asiático (ASEAN) que arrancará el lunes en Kuala Lumpur, con énfasis en la guerra comercial iniciada por Estados Unidos, la continuación de los ataques israelíes sobre Gaza y la crisis en Birmania (Myanmar).

El ministro de Exteriores malasio, Datuk Seri Mohamad Hasan, adelantó que la cumbre de este año incluye por primera vez un espacio trilateral en el que la ASEAN conversará sobre seguridad con China y el Consejo de Cooperación del Golfo (CCG), conformado por Baréin, Kuwait, Omán, Catar, Arabia Saudita y los Emiratos Árabes Unidos.

El canciller malasio llamó a fortalecer urgentemente la integración económica regional para hacer frente a los aranceles anunciados por el presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, -congelados hasta julio- y a la competencia entre las superpotencias, en alusión a las tensiones entre Pekín y Washington. La ASEAN debe asumir un papel activo para afrontar “las turbulencias de los próximos años” y “proteger mejor” la región, en la que viven cerca de 700 millones de personas y en la que se proyecta que el producto interior bruto (PIB) colectivo crezca un 4,7 % este año, en comparación con el 4,2 % de 2024.

El consejo económico de la ASEAN celebró una reunión para abordar este tema y reconoció la necesidad de “romper con el enfoque tradicional y adoptar estrategias más audaces, ágiles y con visión de futuro para salvaguardar y promover los intereses socioeconómicos” de estos países.

En asuntos internacionales, el canciller malasio instó a la ASEAN a “expresarse con firmeza y cohesión en defensa del derecho internacional” en casos como los ataques israelíes sobre Gaza. La comunidad regional “no debe permanecer al margen ante las injusticias globales” y, por el contrario, debe “hacer oír su voz en el escenario internacional para defender a los oprimidos y promover soluciones basadas en el derecho internacional”.

El canciller malasio dijo: “El asedio total de Gaza por parte de las fuerzas israelíes está causando hambrunas y muertes masivas. Las atrocidades cometidas contra el pueblo palestino siguen reflejando indiferencia y dobles raseros”.

Indonesia, la nación con la mayor población musulmana del mundo, se ha plegado al llamamiento de Malasia.

Los cancilleres de la ASEAN reiteraron la necesidad de continuar con los esfuerzos para restablecer la normalidad en Birmania, que vive un conflicto armado entre los militares que detentan el poder y grupos prodemocráticos y guerrillas étnicas.

El canciller malasio dijo: “Instamos a las partes interesadas a cesar las hostilidades y a extender y ampliar el alto el fuego, para facilitar el largo y difícil camino hacia la recuperación y aliviar el sufrimiento del pueblo”, en alusión a la situación del país luego del terremoto del 28 de marzo, que dejó cerca de 3.800 muertos.

title: Trump threatens Apple with 25% tariff: Is now a good time to buy an iPhone?
content: In addition to promising a 50% tariff on the European Union, unless E.U. leaders come to an agreement with the Trump administration within approximately nine days, the president threatened Apple with ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened Apple with 25% tariffs on any iPhone sold, and not made, in the U.S.

Trump posted on Truth Social, his social-media platform, on Friday: "I have long ago informed Tim Cook of Apple (AAPL) that I expect their iPhone's [sic] that will be sold in the United States of America will be manufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else."

Ming-Chi Kuo, TF International Securities analyst, said the costs would likely make such a move prohibitive.

A 25% tariff would mean hundreds of additional dollars on an iPhone price tag.

Prices for the iPhone product line start at $799 and go as high as $1,599 for the iPhone 16 Pro Max.

The iPhone 16 is powered by an "A18 Bionic" chip, integrates artificial intelligence into its camera control and has 85% recycled content.

Alex Kidman, who writes Alex Reviews Tech, said the iPhone 16's 60Hz screen at this price is "indefensible," and cited "inconsistent battery life and overly hot Qi2 charging." (60Hz means the screen updates 60 times every second.).

Some 36% of iPhone buyers in the 12 months ending December 2024 reported having their previous phone for two years or less, compared with 31% in the prior year.

The household savings rate in the U.S. fell to 3.9% in March from 4.1% in February. It averaged 8.4% from 1959 until 2025, reaching an all-time high of 32% in April 2020 and a record low of 1% in July 2005, according to Trading Economics.

Andrzej Skiba, head of U.S. fixed income at RBC Global Asset Management, said the environment surrounding Trump's trade approach may also ensure that borrowing costs remain elevated. "The Fed," he said, "won't likely be able to cut rates in this environment."

title: Trump’s EU tariff threat could cause economic damage beyond Europe
content: President Donald Trump's threat to impose a 50% tariff on all goods coming into the United States from the European Union starting next weekend was the latest zag after several zigs on trade policy ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 50% tariff on all goods coming into the United States from the European Union starting next weekend.
Agathe Demarais, a senior policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations, stated that no one was expecting this and they don’t have a clue as to what it means.
Carsten Brzeski, chief eurozone economist at ING, a Dutch bank, warned that such tariff levels could lead to a combination of higher inflation and slower growth in the United States.
Europe could be pushed into a recession, and global growth would fall.
Julian Hinz, a trade researcher at the Kiel Institute for the World Economy, calculated that U.S. economic growth would drop 1.5%.
Neil Shearing, chief economist at Capital Economics, said the scale of the increase in tariffs, the capricious manner in which they were threatened and the growing size of U.S. budget deficits are unsettling financial markets.
Moody’s downgraded the U.S. credit rating.
Mary E. Lovely, an emeritus professor of economics at Syracuse University, said companies across the board are already raising their assessments of the riskiness of investments in the United States.
Maurice Obstfeld, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics and a former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, said that if you hit back hard, markets will get nervous, and the president will back off.
European officials have prepared a raft of countermeasures in response to higher U.S. tariffs.
Roughly a fifth of EU exports go the United States, and about the same share of American exports go to the European Union.
The European Union has threatened to put tariffs on the American services sector.
If Trump does end up imposing 50% tariffs on June 1, Ireland would be hit the hardest, with an estimated 4% decline in total economic output, according to Capital Economics.
Germany’s gross domestic product is projected to shrink by around 1.5%, Italy’s by 1.2%, France by 0.75% and Spain by 0.5%.
Mark Blyth, a political economist at Brown University, said that in 2008, both the U.S. and Europe had the same size economies.
Now, Europe’s economy is one-third smaller.

title: Trump confirma que retrasa hasta el 9 de julio los aranceles del 50% a la UE
content: Von der Leyen recalca que "la UE y Estados Unidos tienen la relación comercial más relevante y estrecha del mundo" ...
resumen:
Donald Trump, presidente de Estados Unidos, ha aceptado retrasar hasta el 9 de julio los aranceles del 50% a la Unión Europea (UE).

La decisión se anunció tras una conversación telefónica con Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisión Europea.

Trump declaró en su plataforma Truth Social: "He recibido una llamada de Ursula von der Leyen solicitando una prórroga del plazo del 1 de junio sobre el arancel del 50% con respecto al comercio y la Unión Europea. He accedido a la prórroga -9 de julio-".

Von der Leyen informó que mantuvo una "buena conversación" con Trump, abordando las negociaciones comerciales en curso.

Von der Leyen publicó en su cuenta de la red social X que "la UE y Estados Unidos tienen la relación comercial más relevante y estrecha del mundo".

Von der Leyen añadió que "Europa está lista para avanzar rápida y firmemente en las conversaciones. Necesitaremos hasta el 9 de julio para alcanzar un buen acuerdo".

Lars Klingbeil, ministro de Finanzas alemán, expresó "cauto optimismo" sobre las posibilidades de acuerdo.

Paula Pinho, portavoz jefa de la Comisión Europea, indicó que Trump y Von der Leyen acordaron acelerar las negociaciones comerciales y mantenerse en estrecho contacto.

Pinho dijo que "hablamos de la relación comercial más grande y cercana del mundo; estos asuntos son complejos y llevan tiempo".

Pinho precisó que la llamada con Trump "la inició" Von der Leyen y que no abordaron otros asuntos como la guerra en Ucrania sino que "el foco estuvo en las discusiones comerciales".

Trump publicó en su red social Truth Social: "Países de todo el mundo quieren hacer acuerdos comerciales con nosotros. ¡Es maravilloso! ¡Estados Unidos pronto experimentará un crecimiento tremendo y será más fuerte que nunca!".

Carlos Cuerpo, ministro de Economía, afirmó que algunos de los aranceles que ya aplica Estados Unidos están afectando a empresas europeas y hay que "conseguir llegar a un acuerdo equilibrado lo antes posible".

Cuerpo añadió que la UE pondrá todos los esfuerzos necesarios para alcanzar un acuerdo antes del 9 de julio, pero con un "punto de firmeza".

Trump advirtió el pasado viernes que las negociaciones comerciales con la UE "no van a ninguna parte", por lo que amenazó con imponer un arancel del 50% sobre los productos europeos desde el 1 de junio.

title: Aguascalientes registró inversiones por 222 mdd
content: Los anuncios registrados este año provienen de México, Japón, Francia, Estados Unidos, Italia y Canadá; son principalmente proyectos industriales.
resumen:
De enero a abril del 2025, el estado de Aguascalientes sumó anuncios de inversión por 222 millones de dólares, casi 4,444 millones de pesos, con base en los registros internos de la Secretaría de Desarrollo Económico, Ciencia y Tecnología del estado (Sedecyt).

Ese monto reflejó una disminución de 62.6% frente a los 594 millones de dólares que se acumularon en el mismo lapso del año previo.

Los anuncios registrados este año provienen de México, Japón, Francia, Estados Unidos, Italia y Canadá; son principalmente proyectos industriales, en los sectores de tecnologías de la información, automotriz, eléctrico y gestión de residuos industriales.

El secretario de Desarrollo Económico, Ciencia y Tecnología de Aguascalientes, Esaú Garza de Vega, explicó que en el primer cuatrimestre del año fue positiva la confirmación de inversiones en Aguascalientes, atrayendo proyectos tanto internacionales como nacionales.

En abril se anunciaron inversiones originarias de Estados Unidos, de Canadá, entre otros países.

Hay proyectos que están en pausa hasta tener más claridad en la política arancelaria de Estados Unidos, el principal socio comercial de México.

Algunos capitales que fueron anunciados el año pasado, comenzaron a concretarse en este 2025, se reflejan en aquellas empresas que están contratando personal y están próximas a iniciar operaciones.

Aguascalientes, además de recibir proyectos extranjeros, también está recibiendo capitales nacionales.

El desarrollo de proveedores locales y nacionales es una de las acciones que emprende el estado como parte de su estrategia para atraer inversiones, explicó el titular de la Sedecyt.

También se busca atraer proyectos que están relacionados con los procesos productivos que necesita la entidad.

Están priorizando captar inversiones que tengan un enfoque en el cuidado al medio ambiente y que incentiven el desarrollo de las comunidades donde se instalan.

resumen: Se estima que el impacto de las nuevas tarifas a bienes importados y a empresas superará los $5,000 dólares al año para el hogar promedio. Diputados en USA aprobaron 3.5% a remesas. Actualmente, existe un arancel base del 10 % en casi todos los países del mundo. Gran excepción es China, que actualmente enfrenta aranceles de hasta el 134%. El Laboratorio de Presupuesto de la Universidad de Yale ha calculado que los precios al consumidor aumentarán aproximadamente un 3% como resultado de los aranceles. Consumer Reports estima que los precios de los electrodomésticos podrían aumentar entre un 30% y un 40% en los próximos 9 meses.

title: The bad economic vibes are causing more people to stock up on gold
content: Gold bugs are popping up on a wider scale, with global demand for gold bars rising 13% year-over-year in the first quarter.
resumen: The bad economic vibes are causing more people to stock up on gold. Demand for physical gold jumped 13% in the first quarter, according to the World Gold Council. Gold dealers say clients are worried about the dollar's decline, a debt crisis, and other scenarios. Marc Faber, a longtime investor, has been buying gold for decades and telling other people to stock up. He's eyeing a debt crisis, a plunge in asset prices, and soaring inflation. Faber said he buys gold regularly, with the metal comprising 25% of his overall portfolio. Global demand for gold bars climbed to 257 metric tons in the first quarter of 2025, up 13% in a year, according to the World Gold Council. Joe Cavatoni, a market strategist at the World Gold Council, said he believes concerns about the US dollar, economic weakness in the US, and the government's debt and deficit are several reasons gold demand is rising. Genesis Gold Group, a gold dealer, says it's seen intense interest in gold in the last few quarters. Jonathan Rose, the CEO of Genesis, says demand for prepper bars briefly surged after the presidential election and then jumped 20% in the first quarter of 2025. Rose said the number of the firm's clients who insist on holding physical gold has risen to 70%, up from 20% in past years. The price of bullion has climbed 25% in 2025. The S&P 500 is down by about 1% year-to-date. Goldman Sachs recently lowered its recession outlook from 45% to 35%, while Barclays recently removed its forecast for a mild recession. Michael Brown, a senior research strategist at Pepperstone, told BI this week. Michael Boutros, a senior technical strategist at StoneX, told BI. The World Gold Council's Cavatoni added.

title: Long-term bond yields surge around the world
content: WASHINGTON: Around the world, yields on longer-dated sovereign debt have soared as investors question the ability of governments to cover massive budget deficits.
resumen:
Around the world, yields on longer-dated sovereign debt have soared as investors question the ability of governments to cover massive budget deficits.

In the United States, 30-year bond yields last week approached levels last seen in 2007 as President Donald Trump’s tax bill is poised to swell the budget deficit.

Those in Japan exceeded the highest on record in data since 1999, with auctions in both countries drawing tepid demand.

Long-dated bonds in Britain, Germany and Australia also faced selling pressure.

Banks in China lowered their benchmark lending rates for the first time in seven months, and Australia’s central bank cut its key interest rate for a second time this year in a bid to mitigate the impact of US tariffs.

A pullback by central banks and pension funds from bond markets has marginalised a once-dependable source of funding.

The giants of corporate America, from Pfizer Inc to Alphabet Inc, are borrowing in euros like never before as the anxiety triggered by Trump’s tariff threats pushes them to hunt for alternative funding avenues in case their home market freezes up.

In addition to the decisions by Australian and Chinese banks, Iceland, Jamaica, Sri Lanka, Egypt and Indonesia lowered rates.

Officials in Angola, Nigeria, Zambia, Ghana and Paraguay kept borrowing costs unchanged.

Europe UK inflation jumped more than forecast to its highest rate in over a year.

Services inflation accelerated to 5.4% from 4.7%.

Private-sector activity in the euro area unexpectedly shrank in May as services recorded their worst performance in 16 months.

Bulgaria is close to clearing a major hurdle toward euro adoption, putting the Black Sea nation on course to join the currency area next year.

US Chinese shipments of Apple Inc’s iPhone and other mobile devices to the United States dived to their lowest levels since 2011 in April.

Mexico’s annual inflation accelerated more than expected early this month in a report that likely won’t deter central bankers from cutting interest rates again in June.

Argentina’s economy grew less than expected in March.

title: Why Trump lashed out at Europe over trade
content: President Trump’s surprise tariff threat against the European Union came in the midst of deepening frustration on his economic team over the 27-nation bloc’s approach to taxes, regulations and China.
resumen: President Trump threatened to impose 50% tariffs on European imports starting June 1. Trump signaled that he plans to follow through on his threat, saying he is “not looking for a deal" with the EU. Trump’s economic team has been frustrated by what it says is the slow pace of talks. Trump’s advisers have privately expressed irritation to European officials that EU member nations’ differing trade priorities have slowed down the talks. They have complained about what they see as Europe’s cautious approach to the negotiations and what they call the EU’s reluctance to make concrete offers that address U.S. concerns, such as fees on streaming services, value-added taxes, automotive regulations and fines imposed against U.S. companies in antitrust cases. The U.S. has so far not secured a commitment from EU leaders to place new tariffs on Chinese industries. As part of separate trade negotiations with the U.S., the U.K. agreed to move toward imposing tariffs on Chinese steel. That helped seal the U.S.-U.K. trade deal that Trump announced this month. The U.S.-EU tensions boiled over Friday morning. In February, Trump said the EU “was formed in order to screw the United States.". The EU trade chief, Maroš Šefčovič, spoke on a call with U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick hours after Trump’s Truth Social post. After Friday’s call, Šefčovič said the EU is fully engaged in trade talks with the U.S., but is ready to defend its interests. The U.K. reached a deal with the U.S. this month that kept in place Trump’s 10% across-the-board tariffs on U.K. goods. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent raised concerns about the pace of trade talks to EU officials during a meeting of finance ministers in Canada this past week. The EU previously approved tariffs for 21 billion euros of U.S. imports, equivalent to around $24 billion, but put those duties on hold after the Trump administration announced its 90-day pause on some U.S. tariffs. It also proposed targeting a second set of goods, worth up to 95 billion euros, if negotiations with the U.S. break down. In a Fox News interview Friday, Bessent said he hoped the threat of 50% tariffs would “light a fire under the EU.". The EU’s trade chief traveled to Washington in April armed with proposals to cut both sides’ industrial tariffs and for the EU to buy more American energy and soybeans, but left empty-handed.

title: Emmanuel Macron touts France as ‘reliable’ partner for south-east Asia
content: French president’s visit to Vietnam, Indonesia and Singapore will portray Paris as more respectful than US or China ...
resumen: French President Emmanuel Macron has begun a six-day visit to Vietnam, Indonesia and Singapore. He will tout France and Europe as trade and security partners for a region buffeted by tensions between China and the US. Macron arrived in Vietnam late on Sunday. The push for closer trade and security co-operation from Macron is intended to contrast with an increasingly militarily assertive China and the imposition of tariffs by US President Donald Trump on export-reliant countries in the region. An official in the Elysée palace said, “France, along with the European Union, represents a partner that is both reliable, committed to issues of sovereignty, and respectful of their independence.” Trump last month hit Vietnam, Indonesia and other south-east Asian countries with some of his highest “reciprocal” tariff rates after China. The region’s search for new trade opportunities could strengthen ties with the EU. The French official said Macron would emphasise that the EU still backs international trade rules, unlike the current US administration. “We do not want a jungle where the law of the strongest prevails,” the official said. Security concerns will also be high on the agenda, given China’s increasingly assertive naval presence in the South China Sea and tensions with Taiwan. Macron has in the past focused diplomatic efforts on countries including China — where he made a state visit in 2023 — India and Japan, as part of his strategy of positioning France as an Indo-Pacific power. France has several overseas territories in the Indo-Pacific, including la Reunion and Mayotte, which are home to about 1.7mn people. Its naval frigates conduct patrols in the South China Sea and the country has several military bases in the vast region. Vietnam and Singapore already have free trade agreements with the EU, while Indonesia has been in talks to establish one. Vietnam, in October upgraded relations with France to the status of “comprehensive strategic partnership” — the highest level of diplomatic ties offered by Hanoi. Vietnam is stepping up efforts to diversify trade from the US, which accounts for a third of its exports, and to sign free trade agreements with countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America. In Hanoi, Macron is expected to discuss co-operation on economy, defence, security, and energy, according to Vietnamese state media. An agreement on a power transmission line is among one of the deals expected to be signed. After Vietnam, Macron will head to resource-rich Indonesia, where President Prabowo Subianto is seeking foreign investments to spur a slowing economy. Indonesia has previously bought French defence equipment, including Rafale fighter jets and Scorpène submarines. “There may be other contracts announced during the trip,” said Céline Pajon, who heads Japan and Indo-Pacific research at the French Institute of International Relations think-tank. “France and Indonesia intend to raise the defence partnership into something long-term and structural.” The Indonesian government said in a statement this month that Macron’s visit reflected “the commitment of both countries to enhance co-operation in facing global challenges”. Macron plans to discuss diversification of France’s access to materials critical for production of smartphones and semiconductors while in Indonesia. During his final stop of the trip in Singapore, Macron will give a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue, Asia’s largest defence forum. “It is the first time a European leader has been invited to give this speech, and it is in recognition of how Macron has developed a real Indo-Pacific strategy. He also encouraged the EU to adopt one as well,” Pajon said.

title: US-EU trade tensions 'to heighten economic uncertainty' as EU trade commissioner urges 'respect not threats' from US
content: Concerns over a US-EU trade war have been rising over the weekend as the US threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on the EU and the bloc refused to back down, shaking global markets. The US-EU ...
resumen: US-EU trade tensions are rising as the US threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on the EU, and the bloc refused to back down, shaking global markets. The US-EU trade tensions will add more economic uncertainty to the world, according to a Chinese expert. The EU trade commissioner, MaroÅ¡ Å efÄoviÄ, said any potential trade deal between Brussels and Washington must be based on "respect not threats." The US president claimed that "the EU, which was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the US on TRADE, has been very difficult to deal with," and recommended a straight 50 percent Tariff on the EU, starting on June 1, 2025. The US president later escalated his message to the EU - "I'm not looking for a deal," he said. The tariff threat came amid stalled negotiations, with Washington demanding unilateral concessions from Brussels to open up to US business, while the EU has been seeking an agreement that offers mutual gain. The US president's latest remarks follow his April 2 "Liberation Day" announcement of a 39 percent tariff on European goods. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Friday he hopes a new tariff threat from the president would speed along talks with the EU regarding a new trade deal. In a Friday interview with Fox News, Bessent accused the EU of not engaging in "good faith" trade negotiations with the White House. Zhou Mi, a senior research fellow at the Chinese Academy of International Trade and Economic Cooperation, said the US seems eager to ramp up pressure on the EU, possibly due to growing concerns about its domestic economy. The S&P 500 lost 0.7 percent Friday and had its worst week in the last seven. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6 percent, and the Nasdaq composite sank 1 percent. The benchmark STOXX 600 index was down 0.93 percent. Germany's DAX fell by 1.54 percent and France's CAC index slid 1.65 percent. The US was the largest partner for EU exports of goods in 2024, making up 20.6 percent of exports, according to Eurostat. Petroleum oils, medicinal and pharmaceutical products were the EU's most exported group to the US last year. Zhou said that the current unpredictability - driven by tit-for-tat rhetoric - is putting stress on businesses on both sides, including American companies. The French trade minister, Laurent Saint-Martin, said the US' new threats did nothing to help negotiations. Irish Taoiseach MicheÃ¡l Martin described the US proposal of imposing 50 percent tariffs on the EU as "extremely disappointing." Huo Jianguo, a vice chairman of the China Society for World Trade Organization Studies in Beijing, said the EU is one of the US' largest economic partners and remains a significant global power and the US' threat of a 50 percent tariff reflects its eagerness to reach a deal with the EU. A Harris Poll for Bloomberg News found that a majority of US adults, 56 percent, said their household finances would be better off if the US tariffs had not been implemented. The World Economic Situation and Prospects as of mid-2025 recently released by the UN mentioned that higher tariffs and trade policy uncertainty have weakened the global economic outlook for 2025.

title: Trump says he will delay tariffs on European Union until July 9
content: MORRISTOWN, N.J. — President Donald Trump said Sunday that he would delay tariffs that were set to be imposed next week on the European Union until July 9.

title: Trump Delays E.U. Tariffs Until July 9
content: President Trump said he would give the European Union more time to negotiate a trade deal before 50 percent tariffs take effect.
resumen:
President Trump said on Sunday that he would delay imposing 50 percent tariffs on all imports from the European Union until July 9 to allow more time for trade negotiations.

Mr. Trump said that he had spoken to Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, about his recent threat to enact the tariffs on June 1 if a trade deal could not be reached in the next week.

Mr. Trump has expressed frustration over negotiations with the E.U., saying that the union has been slow to offer trade concessions during a 90-day window to reach a deal that satisfies the administration.

On Sunday, Mr. Trump appeared to relent, at least for now.

“The Commission President said that talks will begin rapidly,” Mr. Trump wrote, referring to Ms. von der Leyen.

Ms. von der Leyen, in a separate social media post on Sunday, said that she had a “good call” with Mr. Trump and had conveyed to him that the E.U. needed extra time to reach a trade deal. She said that talks would advance “swiftly and decisively.”

The extension is the latest turnabout by Mr. Trump.

While announcing his recommendation for 50 percent E.U. tariffs on Friday, the president had assailed Europe’s negotiating tactics and expressed no interest in reaching a deal.

Friday’s threat of 50 percent tariffs came after Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent met with European counterparts as part of the Group of 7 meetings in Canada.

Mr. Bessent had given no indication to his counterparts that new tariffs were coming, but he defended them on Friday.

The Treasury Secretary said that Europe has a “collective action” problem and that individual countries in the E.U. did not know how Brussels was negotiating.

Mr. Trump’s tariff threat against the E.U. came weeks after he agreed to partially pause the 145 percent tariffs he had imposed on Chinese imports.

European officials held a call with their American counterparts for trade talks on Friday, and had earlier submitted a term sheet detailing their offers to secure a deal.

European leaders have offered to reduce tariffs on industrial goods to zero if the United States does the same, and to increase purchases of U.S. energy, among other commitments.

In a post on Truth Social Friday morning, Mr. Trump wrote that discussions with the European Union were “going nowhere” and that he was recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1.

Mr. Trump also threatened a 25 percent tariff on imports of smartphones made by Apple and other companies on Friday, saying they should be made in the United States.

Economists at Oxford Economics said that if implemented, the E.U. tariffs and the phone tariffs, combined, would reduce economic growth by 0.2 percentage points, raise inflation by 0.2 percentage points, and increase the unemployment rate by a tenth of a percentage point.

The economists, Ryan Sweet and Bernard Yaros, wrote that the proposed tariffs on the E.U. highlight a key forecast risk, whereby tariffs remain an ongoing tool to be wielded by the Trump administration whenever negotiations hit a snag.

title: Japanese Yen and Aussie Dollar Forecasts: Trade and Central Bank Pivots in Focus
content: AUD/USD climbs on tariff fears, but recession risks linger. RBA and Fed cues, US-China trade headlines, and Beijing policy in sharp focus.
resumen:
Trade tensions spike as Trump threatens 50% EU tariffs, sending USD/JPY down 1.01% on risk-off sentiment.
USD/JPY dropped below 143 on risk-off sentiment.
AUD/USD faces downside risk as US-China trade tensions may weigh on Aussie exports and RBA policy outlook.
Japan’s economy will be in focus on Monday, May 26, influencing the Bank of Japan rate path and USD/JPY trends.
According to preliminary data, the Leading Economic Index dropped from 108.2 in February to 107.7 in March.
A downward revision may temper bets on a Q3 2025 BoJ rate hike, potentially lifting USD/JPY.
A higher print could revive speculation of a Q3 hike, especially after April’s hotter-than-expected core inflation.
A more hawkish BoJ stance may drag the USD/JPY lower.
Economists had already pared back Q3 rate hike bets ahead of Friday’s inflation figures due to escalating tariff concerns.
A Reuters poll (May 7–13) showed: 67% of economists (39 of 58) anticipate no policy change in Q3, up from 36% in April.
52% forecast a 25-basis-point rate hike in 2025.
USD/JPY dropped 1.01% on Friday after President Trump threatened a 50% tariff on EU imports, boosting demand for safe-haven assets like the Yen.
Later in the session, Fed speakers will influence US dollar demand and USD/JPY trends.
Support for a Q3 2025 Fed rate cut could weigh on the US dollar and send USD/JPY toward the 140.309 support level.
Calls to delay rate cuts to assess inflationary impacts from tariffs may drive the pair toward the May 20 high of 145.507.
Bearish USD/JPY Scenario: Rising trade tensions, strong Japanese economic data, or dovish Fed rhetoric could drag USD/JPY toward 140.309.
Bullish USD/JPY Scenario: Easing trade friction, weak Japanese economic indicators, or hawkish Fed cues may lift USD/JPY toward 145 and potentially the 50-day EMA.
On May 26, US-China trade headlines and policy updates from Beijing will influence AUD/USD price action.
On Sunday, May 25, CN Wire reported that Chinese state media emphasized the unresolved nature of the US-China trade conflict, warning that talks would be “protracted and arduous.”
The commentary cited US delay tactics and the risk of renewed escalation if US political and economic pressures ease.
The report concluded that China must prepare for prolonged negotiations and a sustained confrontation.
A prolonged trade war may impact Aussie trade terms, given China accounts for one-third of Australian exports.
With a trade-to-GDP ratio above 50%, weaker demand from China could pressure the RBA into adopting a more dovish stance.
RBA Governor Michele Bullock recently warned that a worsening trade war could push Australia into recession.
She noted: “Australia’s economy could easily be compromised if a trade war between the US and China escalates… The market path is reflecting a possibility of a really bad outcome, pointing to a lower RBA cash rate.”
Rising recession fears and a more dovish RBA rate path may weigh on AUD/USD.
Bearish Aussie dollar Scenario: Renewed US-China tensions, Beijing withholds fresh stimulus, or dovish RBA cues may send AUD/USD toward the 200-day EMA.
Bullish Aussie dollar Scenario: Easing US-China trade tensions, Beijing stimulus, or hawkish RBA signals could send the pair toward the May 14 high of $0.65008.
Later today, US monetary policy will also affect AUD/USD.
Hawkish Fed rhetoric may widen the US-Aussie interest rate differential, potentially pulling AUD/USD toward the 200-day EMA.
Dovish cues favoring a Q3 Fed rate cut would narrow the rate differential, sending the pair toward $0.65008.
Traders should also monitor US fiscal risks and global trade rhetoric.
On May 23, AUD/USD rose 1.29% to $0.64914 as markets digested Trump’s tariff threat on EU imports and growing concerns over US debt levels.
Key Market Drivers to Watch Today: USD/JPY: US-Japan trade talks, Japanese economic data, and BoJ signals.
USD/JPY and AUD/USD: Fed speeches, US economic data, and global trade headlines.
AUD/USD: US-China relations, RBA commentary, and Beijing’s policy stance.

title: President Trump Vows to Prioritize American Interests in World Trade Week Proclamation
content: President Trump's proclamation for World Trade Week focuses on prioritizing American workers and industries in trade policies.
resumen: Como parte de la observancia anual de la Semana Mundial del Comercio, el presidente Donald Trump enfatizó recientemente el enfoque de su administración en la recalibración de las políticas comerciales para priorizar los intereses estadounidenses. En una proclamación, Trump destacó medidas destinadas a fomentar relaciones comerciales equilibradas y recíprocas y expresó su apoyo a los trabajadores estadounidenses que, según él, han sido marginados previamente debido a la globalización. "Durante demasiado tiempo, las élites globalistas vendieron al trabajador estadounidense y permitieron que otros países tomaran injustamente nuestras fábricas, nuestros empleos y nuestros sueños. Esos días terminaron", declaró el Presidente en una proclamación emitida por la Casa Blanca. El Presidente subrayó su dedicación a la creación de un entorno más propicio para la creación de empleo nacional y el fortalecimiento industrial. Señaló que su administración ha sido proactiva en revertir la tendencia de la deslocalización, mediante la promulgación de aranceles y otras medidas comerciales. "Mi Administración está entregando ese futuro", dijo Trump, refiriéndose a una visión que articuló mientras hacía campaña para el cargo. "Desde que asumí el cargo, he tomado medidas para proporcionar una vida mejor para todos los estadounidenses y especialmente para los millones de estadounidenses que quedaron en el camino a medida que los empleos se enviaban al extranjero", según la Casa Blanca. La proclamación de la Casa Blanca también detalló los movimientos de política comercial destinados a frenar la importación de fentanilo y a promover la competitividad estadounidense en el extranjero. Elogió la introducción de nuevos acuerdos comerciales, como el acuerdo comercial entre Estados Unidos y el Reino Unido, que buscan crear oportunidades para las empresas estadounidenses a nivel internacional. El Presidente se comprometió a combatir las prácticas comerciales desleales que afectan a una amplia franja de la población estadounidense, desde "agricultores y pescadores hasta empresarios y todos los demás", según la Casa Blanca. Trump expresó una firme determinación de perpetuar una estrategia de "Estados Unidos primero" en todas las negociaciones comerciales y el desarrollo de políticas. "Como Presidente, siempre pondré los intereses de Estados Unidos primero", afirmó. "Juntos, construiremos una nueva Edad de Oro para Estados Unidos con un fuerte crecimiento económico y políticas comerciales de Estados Unidos primero que protejan a nuestros trabajadores, fortalezcan nuestras industrias y desbloqueen el Sueño Americano para todos los ciudadanos". El domingo pasado hasta ayer fueron designados como la Semana Mundial del Comercio, invitando a la celebración de las contribuciones del comercio estadounidense bajo la directiva de Trump, según lo detallado por la Casa Blanca.

title: Tariff Uncertainties, Part 3: The Bond Markets
content: There are five important Treasury market anomalies to consider.
resumen:
The Treasury Bond market experienced significant volatility following the announcement of new high-tariff policies on April 2, with the market briefly appearing to be on the verge of collapse. The "queasiness" in the Treasury market was cited as the reason that tariff proposals were quickly put on hold on April 9. The market recovered, suggesting the relationship between tariffs and bond market turmoil had been demonstrated.

However, this conclusion is likely false for two reasons:

1.  **Scale:** The projected impact of tariffs on inflation or growth is small relative to the economy.
2.  **Treasury market anomalies:** The Treasury market has been behaving strangely for several years, unrelated to tariffs or trade policy.

There are five important Treasury market anomalies to consider:

1.  The Treasury market experienced its longest and deepest yield curve inversion ever, from July 2022 to September 2024, which did not lead to or predict a recession.
2.  This inversion was closely tied to reversals in Federal Reserve monetary policy, which had not happened in previous inversions.
3.  In September, the Treasury market broke a decades-long relationship between the Fed’s official interest rates and yields on Treasury bonds, potentially indicating the Fed's interest rate policy lever may have ceased to function.
4.  In early April, the Treasury bond market deviated from the usual crisis-response pattern, with a massive bond sell-off.
5.  Complex trading strategies like swap-spreads and “basis trades” have changed the tenor of the market in the direction of greater speculation, increased leverage, rising volatility, sometimes intensely crowded trades, and heightened sensitivity to external shocks.

The "Liberation Day" tariff shock set the stock market ringing like a bell, with the worst two-day decline in history, followed by a gain, and then more back and forth. Volatility exploded. The 10-Year Treasury Bond yield rose 64 basis points in two days, and Treasurys lost more than 5% in value in one week. Bond market volatility, as measured by the MOVE Index, surged more than 3 standard deviations above its recent average. Technical symptoms of bond market stress appeared, including a "significant" deterioration in liquidity. Contagion spread to global bond markets. The turbulence stirred fears that the Treasury market could seize up. The market deviated from the established crisis-response script.

Then, the storm blew over. The Vix returned to normal. The stock market recovered its losses rapidly. The Treasury bond market stabilized. Daily trading volatility returned to normal. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fluctuated on average just 4 basis points per day. Even the dollar was up 3%. The MOVE Index was back to its pre-April 1 average. The normal economic indicators are coming in with generally positive readings. Corporate earnings have been strong. The Fed reported that “economic activity has continued to expand at a solid pace.”

The real impact of tariffs, if implemented, would not likely be large enough to unhinge the massive Treasury bond market. The imposition of tariffs would amount to a scattering of one-time taxes across the economy. The Tax Foundation calculated that the 2018 tariffs resulted in tariff duties of about $200-300 per household annually– about 0.3% of the median household income. The Peterson Institute estimated that Liberation Day tariffs would cost consumers about $1200-1500 per household. The Penn Wharton Budget model forecast a similar reduction of about 0.4% of GDP in 2030. The Yale Budget Lab’s maximalist estimate of the impact of the tariffs included in the Liberation Day proposal was higher – $4800 per household, or about 2.1% of GDP.

The Treasury bond market is currently valued at 95% of U.S. GDP. It is the deepest, most liquid, and most efficient financial market in the world. It embodies an immense power to determine the price of credit everywhere. Treasurys set the rate of return on trillions of dollars of bonds held in the reserves of all major central banks, and trillions more in the portfolios of investors here and abroad – almost $29 Tn in all. The market trades more than $1 Tn per day.

The bond market is responding more to the Fed policy than to tariff talk. The Federal Reserve seems currently unable to move market interest rates in the desired policy direction. The "preconditions" in the bond market – especially the unwinding of the “basis trade” – were the major contributors to the market turbulence. Tariff talk was a trigger, but the large-scale market-clearing of Treasurys in a short time feels much more like a crowded trade unwinding than a response to the substantive economics of tariffs.

title: How American Retailers Are Navigating Trump’s Volatile Trade Policy
content: Observer spoke with dozens of retail CEOs and founders, consumer experts and supply chain strategists about how they are navigating tariffs.
resumen:
In 2025, tariffs have emerged as a new "force majeure" for American retailers due to erratic tariff policies tied to Trump’s second-term agenda. Businesses are facing a high-stakes guessing game in navigating pricing, planning, and logistics, with trade alliances dissolving overnight and tariff schedules changing rapidly. Preserving optionality is now a survival skill.

Companies are reengineering operations and supply chains to withstand what many call a “Trump majeure.” Bill London, an international attorney at Kimura London & White, notes that businesses are revisiting contracts to insert renegotiation clauses and price adjustment mechanisms triggered by tariff shifts.

Charlie Youakim, CEO and co-founder of Sezzle, observes that pure e-commerce retailers, especially those reliant on Chinese manufacturing, are scrambling, reworking logistics, and repricing inventory. While there's no panic, there is urgency.

Ross Widmoyer, CEO of Faribault Mill, has embraced a hyper-local model, sourcing inputs domestically, which has provided insulation and agility. Faribault Mill employs around 100 people and brings in nearly $20 million in annual revenue.

Steve Skillings, founder of BusyBox, faces shutting down due to skyrocketing component costs from tariffs.

Jason Wingate, co-founder of Zlumber, emphasizes the need for structural flexibility, including diversified suppliers, agile freight partners, and manufacturing options.

Many companies have relied on China for manufacturing, but this reliance is becoming precarious. Lee Mayer, CEO of Havenly Brands, is skeptical of rapid re-shoring due to price hikes. David’s Bridal has restructured its global supply chain, shifting production away from China. Mattel has reduced its manufacturing reliance on China. Ben Koren, CEO of Frameology, re-shored production years ago.

Companies are responding in different ways: shifting production, building structural flexibility, leaning into innovation, or engaging in policy advocacy. Emily Hosie, founder of REBEL, is lobbying for tariff exemptions on baby products. Keegan Nesvacil, CEO of Woodland Tools, describes a “design-for-resilience” model.

Many large brands have opted to stock up on inventory.

Resilience now depends on agility, optionality, and the recognition that there’s no cookie-cutter playbook.

title: Trump Agrees To Extend 50% Tariffs On Europe Until July 9: 'It Was My Privilege To Do So'
content: Trump agreed to extend tariff deadline to July 9, 2025 after receiving call from Ursula von der Leyen, amid ongoing trade tensions between US and EU.
resumen: Donald Trump announced on Sunday that he received a call from Ursula von der Leyen, the President of the European Commission, requesting an extension on the impending 50% tariff deadline. The original deadline was set for June 1, but Trump agreed to extend it to July 9, 2025. Trump stated on Truth Social that the Commission President assured him that negotiations would commence swiftly. Trump expressed his willingness to grant the extension, describing it as his “privilege to do so.” Von der Leyen said on X that she had a “good call” with Trump. She had requested time until July 9 to reach a “good deal.” Trump’s decision to extend the deadline follows his previous threat to impose a 50% tariff on all European Union imports.

title: Las consecuencias económicas de las políticas de Trump
content: Mientras el presidente estadounidense siembra confusión e incertidumbre en todo el mundo, es comprensible que las perturbaciones a corto plazo acaparen la mayor parte de la atención. Pero es probable ...
resumen: El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, introdujo aranceles, que luego puso en pausa. Algunos de los efectos de las políticas de Trump sobre la economía de Estados Unidos y del mundo son previsibles. Algunas áreas de Estados Unidos sufrirán escasez de bienes importados, sobre todo de procedencia asiática. La demanda agregada se deprimirá. El acuerdo entre China y Estados Unidos para la suspensión de los aranceles por 90 días no resuelve por completo la incertidumbre. Las importaciones solo suponen un 14% del PIB, y las exportaciones algo más del 11%. La agenda desreguladora de la administración Trump puede estimular el crecimiento liberando una ola de inversión local. La economía estadounidense equivale al 25% del PIB mundial. El Fondo Monetario Internacional predice que el impacto de los aranceles de Trump sobre el crecimiento será mayor en Estados Unidos (-0,9%), seguido por Canadá y China (-0,6%) y luego Japón (-0,5%). El FMI también pronostica una caída del 0,5% para Reino Unido, y para las principales economías de Europa continental se prevé pérdidas del 0,3% o menos. A largo plazo, es probable que los efectos de la política arancelaria de Trump sean mayores. Los líderes políticos, los funcionarios y las empresas han comenzado a actualizar sus estrategias en busca de resiliencia y seguridad. Europa ha iniciado un marcado aumento del gasto en defensa. Muchas economías diversificarán sus intercambios comerciales. Canadá buscará ampliar sus vínculos comerciales y de inversión y reducir barreras internas al comercio. La estabilidad a largo plazo de la economía y del sistema financiero estadounidenses corren riesgo. Los flujos de inversión extranjera se alejen de Estados Unidos. La crema del talento científico y tecnológico quiera irse a otra parte. La presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, formuló una invitación explícita a investigadores para que se radiquen en Europa. Las instituciones y marcos multilaterales se debían una modernización. Los líderes de las demás economías desarrolladas (y casi todas las emergentes) siguen comprometidos con una versión de vinculación multilateral. Los intentos de construir un multilateralismo nuevo y más complejo continuarán, con escaso aporte de Estados Unidos. La Unión Europea y las principales economías emergentes (en particular China) llevarán la delantera. El papel destacado de Estados Unidos en los esquemas de seguridad asiáticos complicará este proceso. Los efectos a más largo plazo de algunas de las políticas de la administración Trump serán más significativos, amplios y sólo parcialmente reversibles.

title: México, puente para reforzar lazos de Europa con América: Tajani
content: CIUDAD DE MÉXICO, 25 de mayo de 2025.-México puede ser un puente para reforzar los lazos de Europa con América del Norte y del Sur, dijo el ministro de Asuntos Exteriores y de Cooperación ...
resumen:
El ministro de Asuntos Exteriores y de Cooperación Internacional de la República Italiana, Antonio Tajani, de visita en la UNAM, dijo que México puede ser un puente para reforzar los lazos de Europa con América del Norte y del Sur.

Tajani ofreció la conferencia magistral Geopolítica Europa y América Latina, ante estudiantes de Relaciones Internacionales, profesores, investigadores y funcionarios universitarios reunidos en el auditorio del tercer piso de la Torre de Rectoría.

Tajani propuso trabajar por la paz en el mundo, reforzando la estructura de la Organización de las Naciones Unidas (ONU); impulsar el comercio mundial; y defender la democracia como modelo político.

Tajani señaló que México puede ser un puente para reforzar las relaciones de Europa con América del Norte y del Sur.

Tajani consideró que China tiende a ser la reina de la civilización internacional, más a nivel económico que militar.

Tajani comentó que hay que considerar a India, con más habitantes que China y relaciones muy buenas con rusos, chinos y estadounidenses; así como a África, un continente con poblaciones pobres, pero con materias primas fundamentales para todos los países industriales.

Tajani apuntó que el bloque de América del Norte (Canadá, Estados Unidos y México) va a ser siempre una figura importante del mundo.

Tajani sostuvo que trabajar para un gran mercado económico libre -México, Canadá, Estados Unidos y Europa- sería la mejor solución contra la pobreza y para ayudar a todas las empresas.

Alejandro Chanona Burguete, director de la Facultad de Ciencias Políticas y Sociales, resaltó que la UNAM se distingue por su vocación universal, su compromiso con la democracia y los derechos humanos, así como su permanente interés en el análisis crítico de los fenómenos políticos globales.

Chanona Burguete señaló que la trayectoria política y humana de Tajani encaja justamente en esos valores.
